26 yr old. Ive had sleeping problems and become severely depressed the last 3 years, i also live very close to the polar circle and its 24/7 darkness here. So i really feel i need to go somewhere sunny and just relax, snorkle, swim, take a diver cert and enjoy life.

Ive got a full summer vacation of a month that i need to use before the end of March otherwise it will be converted into salary, and i would rather use it to go somewhere. Im thinking the Maldives.

Ive got about 10 thousand dollars in savings total. I looked at different hostels and costs and the travel cost back and forth from my country would be 1k, then a cheap simple hotel which ive looked at there are multiple around the maldives that go for around 70 dollars a night or similar so it would be around 1.5 k usd for 3 entire weeks.

and i suppose another 1k for perhaps food and transport and activities while there. So a grand total of maybe 3.5 thousand dollars?

I saw this guy and it looked pretty nice where he was and cheap
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=I56oieL7IQA
He was on an Island called Omadhoo, it doesnt have to be specifically this island, im just using it as an example.

Im only interested in snorkling beatiful reefs, getting sunlight and swimming/enjoying life/eating good food. Not any ultra luxury or partying or anything like that

Do you think its a good idea? Got any better suggestions for what im looking for?

i would be going in March. It looks like one of those places you can really focus on revitalizing yourself and simply relax.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2390893
I've done two families together and the understanding that we could split up meant a big argument just resulted in splitting for a day and joining back up after having cooled off. My scattershot advice:

Try to get people to say what they want to do as early as possible. Some people may want to watch Fantasmic, some may want a themed dinner, etc. Finding out late in the day can lead to arguments.
Sort out a basic itinerary early. Allow for flexy days if someone wants to go to Gatorworld, do an airboat ride, there are multiple days with activities not set in stone where you can split up for the whole day.
Do not go to Magic Kingdom on the weekend. Chances are you're flying in on the weekend, they will want their first day to be at the Magic Kingdom. Do not do it, tell them how that park is hell on weekends.
Try to stick together for the "main" days, the more people riding on things together, the better.
Sort out your toilet breaks and minimise them. You waste so much fucking time in big groups because of constant long toilet breaks.
Don't over pressure people to go on rides they can't take, not only may they have a miserable time, they may believe they're going to keep getting pressured for other rides they don't want to go on.
Continuing on that let people go on other rides whilst they wait, you can meet after.
Try to avoid quiet people getting dominated: "Lol no we don't want to go on the Little Mermaid ride!" "oh... ok". Especially likely to happen to people who can't take big coasters. Try to stop dominant voices getting into the habit of speaking for the group
Avoid any people becoming the "+2". Easy for the same people to always be the last ones in the line who go in a different car from everyone else on rides.
Sort out phones, everyone must be contactable. Parks have free wifi everywhere if people don't have roaming.
Don't make people reliant on "the group" for transport

Get everyone to get the My Disney Experience app and link it all together.

>>2391959
It's a technicality. Disney even coined the term "theme park". This has nothing to do with Disney adults. My original point was people shit on regional parks by saying Walt took his daughters to one and came up with the idea for Disneyland. But none of these parks existed, the parks that existed back then were like Coney Islands and trolley parks and carnivals.

Some of those old parks became larger regional parks, but most popular regional parks were OPENLY copying the Disneyland model. For example, Angus Wynne, the creator of Six Flags, created Six Flags Over Texas after visiting Disneyland to make something similar but themed to Texas. These parks borrowed Disneyland design elements like the themed lands, hub and spoke layout, garbage cans everywhere, and had cheap facsimiles of popular attractions. Theming was kitschy but so was early Disneyland until the expansions in the late 60s and onward.

You don't need to be an autistic circumcised dickhead about it. Fuck off

>What do you think is a reasonable price outlay for 2 people going to Orlando (Dis/Uni) for 2 weeks
Depends where you want to stay.
Tickets alone will cost you basically £1k per person if you want Disney, Universal and Seaworld.
Flights will be upwards of £2k total depending on time of day/year.
Hotels start at around £800 per person for a value place like Universal's Endless Summer resort, but I prefer staying in a Villa which start at £1200.
There was a nice privately owned Villa I stayed at twice so try looking into that.
https://floridavillawithpool.co.uk/

I think you're looking at £3000 as a cheapest possible option. Flights, budget hotel, Universal and Disney.tickets

Add £2000 for mid range Disney
Add £800 for car hire ($30 per day parking at Disney, thankfully scrapped hotel car parking fees)

$100-$150 per day spending money is a reasonable estimate. Add more if you plan on doing sit down restaurants

posts.com:
Is Car Hire even necessary for Florida?
If you stay onsite in Disney or Universal, Im assuming youll just be getting an Uber to the other main parks.
If you stay at Disney, just get the bus to Disney Springs and get an uber to wherever you want to go along International Drive, or hop on the I-Trolley to cut down on costs.

Obviously if you stay off site at a Villa youre probably looking at a minimum of $40 per day with Uber, so even taking a flat rate of 2 weeks thats 12 days coming in at about $500. So even if car rental is around $600-800 you could probably make uber work in your favour, allowing for extra trips per day and still coming under the total cost of a car (that also requires petrol & parking fees in places)

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2394677
I think what you'll find, if you're a first timer, is that there's probably more you'll want to do offsite than you think there is and then sticking to a predetermined uber budget will be difficult. There are tons of places to see and eat at in that area and even more if you're willing to drive a little further (such as Cape Canaveral). Being able to do that on your schedule or whim maximizes your own time which, on a vacation, seems worth it. If you're going to be there a week or more, I can't imagine not having a rental car, at least for part of the stay.

Don't forget that Disney buses are notorious for taking a long time to get around with. As I said, it could be worth it to you to pay more to skip waiting around at bus stops.

just an FYI if you're not doing Disney or a villa, British Airways Holidays and Virgin often massively markup their flight-only prices so it can be cheaper booking them together (or booking with a company they codeshare with like Delta).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2395494

Alton Towers has some incredible coasters, but its entirely dependant on the context.

For the UK, its clearly the leading theme park.
Compared to Americas biggest parks, its alright.

Nemesis has closed. They are doing a complete track rebuild. It was starting to show its age, so the new track should be much smoother. Im not sure if its a new layout, or just new steel.

Rita, Queen of Speed is pretty awesome. Although its very short, and compared to things like Top Speed Dragsters its fairly tame.

Thirteen, has its moments, although when you ride it, the track looks so thing and frail you can be amazed it stands up.

Oblivion has its charm. The worlds first vertical drop coaster (even if it was only an 89 degree drop). But compared to Shiekra or Baron, its just a drop. The ride will be over very quick. Theres no other elements.

Smiler is hands down their best ride. Its so impressive to see so many elements crammed into such a small space. I wish more parks would do this. You dont always need height and speed. Well executed elements in close proximity to one another are great.

Air, or Galactica is fairly boring. You spend a lot of time upside down on your back, and miss a lot of the layout. Sure it feels a bit like your flying, but keep me face down for most of it. Its a poor mans version of Manta

It's a shame that UK parks are not only massively seasonal but that for half the time they're open, the weather is miserable.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2394865
I have some friends in Fukui but it's really a wonderful city. A lot of people recommend the dinosaur museum (which i think is being renovated right now unfortunately) but it's also right next to Echizen which was at one point one of the central hubs of traditional industry in feudal japan. There are a lot of museums such as the bamboo museum and specialty shops for their world renowned cutlery. Also within train distance are the Tojinbo cliffs, which are a neat sightseeing spot with a couple of shops around it. There's also a bunch of seafood markets here and there which have Echizen snow crab, which is supposed to be some of the best in Japan. Fukui itself might be more of a standard city, it has a few castles but they have a restaurant chain called Europa which has some of the best tonkotsu i've ever eaten. In August they also have a big fireworks festival if you're into that. Please visit if you have the chance, it should be a stop on the JR West line if you have a pass.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2394674
Have you looked into renting jiko bukken (事故物件) apartments?They're apartments where the previous tenant died in, either murder, accident, or suicide. According to Japanese law the landlord has to disclose to the potential new tenants about the death of the previous tenant which makes the property less valuable due to superstitions. These apartments are thus cheaper and there's less competition to get them as the natives would rather stay away from those apartments.

Shinkansen? Do you have a reserve seat? Then just queue early and put it in the overhead compartment(if it fits) or in the luggage area. No one cares, first come first serve. Everyone does it - hop on any train that goes to Niigata or Nagano and it will be full of ski/snowboard bags during winter.

Local trains? Just hold on to it and keep it in front of you. Everyone will know you're a tourist so you will get a pass, but it sounds like a pain in the ass.

Lockers? It depends. There are varying sizes, and there large can mean 30L or 60L, fuck if I know. Instead of lockers, look for luggage storage services instead if you want to be sure.

posts.com: If I’m going from the Chuo line to the Osaka loop line do I need to pay separate train fares for each line with my IC card? Or is there a way to just pay for it at the end of my osaka loop line and get some sort of discount?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2395529
1) if you need to change trains and you go from one station to another you need to pay twice. The first time you tap a card when you're going in to the station you "sign in" and then you tap again once you leave the station you get off you "sign out" and the payment is displayed on the machine. If you change trains on the same station you only pay at the last station you get off on.
2) If you're going from a JR line to a local line or vice versa you generally have to pay even if it is on the same station as you're traveling with two different companies, so in the end you'll pay twice.
3) There's usually no discount. You'll pay for the distance traveled, or some lines will have a flat rate but that's usually buses rather than trains
>pic rel. Osaka Metro line map showing Chuo line as an Osaka Metro line and Osaka Loop as a JR line
>read: You will have to pay twice

I'm honestly considering just overnighting my luggage next trip in fall. I found it a pain in the ass on local trains to haul that shit, especially in smaller local trains and buses. Anyway as for reserving seats it's fairly easy, just go to any major JR station that has shinkansen platforms and there will be an employee there who will assist you with that. You can choose the seat and if you want to keep your luggage ask if they have the extra room seats. They're nothing fancy and can probably fit a smaller suitcase, I had a little trouble with our large cases so one had to go overhead and one behind when we had those seats.
Lockers are shit IMHO almost lost our Akihabara haul on the first trip because we left our things in a locker for the day. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2395497
>Use skyscanner.
>Search your flight on the 'whole month' option (try multiple months as well).
>Select the cheapest combination of days.
>Use carry-on luggage only.
>Do not purchase any extras for the flight.
>Be prepared to spend upwards of 6 hours in an airport during a layover.

What I have learnt:
Don't bother trying to save an extra $20 by 'mixing and matching' airlines when you only have a few hours between the flights. If the earlier flight is delayed and you miss your next flight (more likely than you'd think) the airlines probably won't help you. Mixing and matching airlines is acceptable when you have days between flights.
If the flights you're looking at have unfortunately long layovers (16 hours+), see about staying in the layover destination for a day or two and getting the flight to your real destination later. You do this by booking a return flight to the layover destination and a return flight from the layover destination to the real destination.
Most of the time cheap airlines are perfectly fine and anyone who wants to spend an extra $500+ just to get a shitty meal and see shitty movies through a shitty chair screen for 12 hours is an idiot. Purchase a good phone battery bank, put some games or movies on your phone and enjoy, being a little bored for a few hours is absolutely worth the money saved by flying cheap.
Cheap airlines are known for not refunding your ticket so don't buy the ticket if you aren't sure you will be going unless you're willing to take the risk.

You may want to think about the South more than the North.
There are plenty of castles but there is more touristy things to do.
For Castles you have Cardiff Castle and Caerphilly. You can go to the Roman museum in Caerleon (it's a good day trip from Cardiff and accessible with public transport) and see the remains of a Roman amphitheater there and Roman museum.
For Arthur/Merlin stuff you can visit Craig-y-Dinas in the vale of Neath where according to legend Arthur is inside asleep. Some other legends say it was the last place in Britain that faeries were seen.
Also in the area you have some pretty cool waterfalls which are an easy to walk to and the Dan Yr Ogof caves which are open to tourists aren't so far away.

I post this in every Vegas thread, but here goes,

For hiking, go to Red Rocks. Park at the Calico Basin parking area for free. Climb to the top. It's a crazy scramble up through crevices and over giant boulders.

Another awesome hike is the Arizona Hot Springs trail. You hike through a slot canyon. There are some awesome hot springs you can bath in. You can actually climb down all the way to the Colorado River.

For food, go to West Spring Mountain and eat in Chinatown. Hachi, Viet Noodle House, Ramen Sora, Ichiza are all amazing.

For gambling, I'd go downtown. The table limits are lower. You get more bang for your buck. Fremont Street at night is always fucking crazy fun for people watching. The best game in vegas is craps. Best odds and the most entertaining. Play the pass line and back up your bet with odds.

Weed is legal. Just buy your drugs at a legal weed store. Don't do business with drug dealers in vegas. You'll get murdered.

The Cirque shows are all pretty good. Ka is probably my favorite. One show is enough.

posts.com:
A few things I learnt from my trip:

Stock up on drinks and snacks at Walgreens or Target next to the MGM, don't buy any cans, bottles or snacks at a hotel.

Fremont Street and Circus Circus are both complete bitches to get to. Don't expect to walk to them or be able to get the monorail to them.

The buffets are terrible value for money now and half of them a "brunch" buffets which mean they're split between breakfast and lunch so the range suffers. Maybe do one for the novelty but just eat at regular restaurants for the rest, you'll get better food and you can still fill yourself up and have it come out cheaper.

If you're a light sleeper, either get some white noise generator or turn the fan on the AC up. Noisy drunk people and heavy doors that slam hard are a bitch.

Older and smaller strip hotels gaming floors either have eye watering levels of cigarette smoke or pump out huge amounts air freshener to counter it. If you're intending to use your hotel to game and can't deal with smoke, don't stay at one of the cheap "classic" strip hotels.

Comp drinks servers all but run past you in my experience. You have to be proactive or at least keep a look out to get drinks.

I ended up using the monorail far more than I was expecting. It's worth getting a multi-day ticket if you're at a hotel that has a station. There are various ways of getting discounts (MyVegas lets you exchange easy to get points for vouchers and the monorail vouchers are one of the better vouchers you can earn that isn't always out of stock).

Slots are low odds and low volatility (at least on the strip). Very unlikely they'll do anything other than slowly drain away your money.

Bluffing is a much smaller part of poker than you'd think. Call with OK hands, raise with good hands. You should be folding 75% of your hands at least. If you have a strong starting hand, don't limp. At lower limit tables the guy who raises first preflop (unless he gets re-raised) wins most hands

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2395044
>Lowest possible volitility:
You play $1 and the reels come in $0.85 every single spin. Most of the money paid out by the slot goes on low wins

>Highest possible volitility:
Every 1,100,000 spins, it wins $1,000,000 and never wins outside of that. Most of the money paid up by the slot goes on high win

US slots are basically all low X bet wins. They may have $10,000 jackpots but they never pay out on low stakes and even if people play the max stakes of ~$4 you're still going to go an entire holiday never having seen anyone hit then (and a 2500x max win is considered low for a slot) . Most people will see a steady stream of < 10x wins and features that almost never go above 50x.

With low volitility, people play for a long time, but almost no one comes out with a profit. With high volilitility, people who don't win get their money drained quickly but a % of people leave the slots having had a massive win.

Outside observation: It was always a racist country. It was simply slightly less racist than its southern neighbor, the United States.

Canada’s historical mistreatment of its First Nations citizens is on display for the world to see. While the nation had reached some accommodations with the various tribes, it’s still very clear that the First Nations people are viewed as being second class citizens in many areas of Canada, particularly in areas with large populations of tribal members. The poor state of infrastructure on many of the reserves also clearly indicate that the government’s priority is not the residents of those areas.

As far as Blacks: While Canada was never as racist as the Deep South of the United States, segregation (de jure and de facto) were very common in Canada until the 1960s. Black Canadians who descended from either people brought over as slaves, former sea farers and escaped American slaves, lived in segregated areas, faced discrimination for jobs and financing and were often harassed by law enforcement and White Canadians. While this changed drastically in the last 50 years ( due in part to changes in the US and an influx of Afro-Carribbeans and African immigrants and refugees) , racism is not uncommon in areas of Canada which have small non-White populations.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2393549
Asians - Both East and South Asians have experienced a great deal of discrimination in Canada, although the fact that many came to Canada with wealth or were able to move into the middle and upper classes within a generation or so seems to have tempered this somewhat. Just as in the United States, most Asians and their descendants live in and around the major cities and urban areas, so the prejudice that they experience isn’t as widespread as the prejudice against Blacks and First Nations people seems to be. It does , however exists as referenced below.

Latinos - The recent influx of Latinos into the country seems to have provoked some prejudice against. However, Canada’s Latino population is relatively small, most confined to the cities, and it really hasn’t integrated into the mainstream. As climate change worsens and it becomes clear that Canada can support many more people than its harsh winters currently allows, there are likely to be more immigrations from Latino majority nations which are likely to face the need to flee that change. If history is any indicator if/when their numbers increase, so will the prejudice and discrimination that they face.

Canada is not a bad country, and its racism isn’t as profound as it is in many areas of the United States. It’s not “turning racist.” It IS racist, but it is also slightly less so than many other countries in the Western world.

It's not too bad at places with a high elevation unless there's a heat wave. Joshua Tree will be too hot but Arches or even the top of GC will be fine. Anything in the pnw will be very comfy.

You're really not getting out of crowded national parks if you insist on going during the busiest time of the year.

National park visitation increased greatly during the pandemic when indoor entertainment closed and hasn't returned to normal.

Kings Canyon will get less visitation than Yosemite though and Canyonlands less than Arches so go to the ones that are near another park but not the favorite. But don't completely skip Arches.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2395348

Lisbon is better, but don't sleep on Porto. Lisbon has more shit to do, especially in the daytime. Lisbon has a relaxed, friendly vibe. Lisbon is closer to Algarve in the south. Huge variety of food. Everything is centrally located and it's super simple to see a bunch of cool shit.

Porto is more of a working city. It's cheaper, the people can actually afford to live and work there. It's not pretentious, and has a gritty quality that's admirable. Lots of beauty on the water. Has more pubs, meat sandwiches, and people are like 35-50 years old in Porto whereas they might be 20-35 in Lisbon. Porto is in the north and is near the vineyard region (Duoro valley) if you're into taking a boat cruise into a vineyard landscape

If you have time you should totally see both, but Lisbon for me was better. Lisbon you can definitely stay a week in to see the whole thing. Porto you could see everything in 3-4 days.

Hong Kong on the other hand is as cyberpunk as a human city can get in real life.

There is no photoshop in this image. This is Mong kok, the most densely populated neighborhood in the world. This vicinity all the way to the south feels like you're in basically Night City (or rather, NC feels like HK). Full of neons, gigantic complex sprawls with 20 to 30 store buildings, soot build up all over the fucking place.Some places are pretty cramped, but you can mostly navigate the area without any problem. Walking all the way south gets you to hong kong island, which is the financial district and has its own vibe too. It's the only city that does it for me. The other ones have their own vibe and it is not blade runner or the cyberpunk genre in general. Even Tokyo is milder than what people picture it. You want grit, go to Hong Kong. In contrast, Macau actually is a nice break since you've got all that south european mediterranean feel that is pretty relaxing. Feels like summer in Barcelona, seriously.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2381428
It really all depends on your tastes, anon. But if you want the most bang for your buck, plan a trip to do two of these cities at the same time. For example, the ferry from HK to Macau is only 40 bucks (roundtrip) and Shenzhen is right at the border. So you could like, leave a day or two for visiting Macau and do the rest of the week in Hong Kong visiting the city, museums, the nearby greenery or simply just having fun. Same goes for Singapore and Kuala lumpur, a simple bus trip of a few hours gets you from one to the other.

Same goes for Japan. Kyoto and Osaka (+kobe) are basically the same city. only issue is if you want to do Tokyo too, in which case an overnight bus trip (500km) won't cost much. And Same goes for Seoul/Busan (300km)
Taking this into account, you can easily see that HK/Shenzhen/Macau is a great deal and so is Kyoto/Osaka/Kobe (kobe is definitely worth a visit !), especially if you can fit Tokyo into your timetable/budget. I'd also put Malacca/Kuala Lumpur/Singapore as another trio worth visiting.

On the other hand, there are places where it's worth just taking 2-4 weeks, find an appartment or airbnb to rent, and pretend you've lived there all your life. These places are Chongqing and Taipei, in my opinion. They're relatively peaceful places with not much shit to do but basically go on a walking adventure around the city, discover the people, hear their stories. Maybe have a love story. Maybe look at the job situation so you can make it there. Who knows.

Here's the Cyberpunk rankings of the cities I've visited so far:

Tokyo (7/10) (overated- too clean and tidy)
Seoul (7/10) (overated- has too much of a boring American "grid" like layout)
Busan (8/10) (underated- multiple skyscraper urban cores tucked in between mountains and hills filled with favela looking "slums", good mix of grit and modern/sleek)
Kyoto (0/10) (Asking if Kyoto is Cyberpunk is like asking if Florence, Italy is Cyberpunk. No.)
Jakarta (6/10) (too "low life" and not enough "high tech", its just a giant open sewer slum with some high end shopping malls in the center)

Some others
Bangkok (9/10) (100% Blade Runner/Night City, my favorite on this list, only reason its not a 10 is because I havent been to China yet which I imagine would take all perfect 10/10 rankings)
Saigon (8/10) (the "low life" aspect among neon grit is well represented, but a little lacking in the balance of modern infrastructure, skyscrapers and urban verticality outside of a very small area of District 1- give it time though, the city is building up fast and will probably take a 10/10 spot some day)

Keep in mind, this was all before COVID though- 2018 and 2019- and I imagine lockdowns killed any sort of that Cyberpunk "wild west", hustle and bustle feeling these places used to have. I imagine theyre all a lot quieter now and all the small businesses are mostly shuttered.

posts.name: Tolstoi
posts.com:
Dear /trv/eterans,

I have decided to create a thread for those interested in general information regarding living abroad. I think a lot of threads tend to discuss some singular aspects of living in certain countries, but I feel like regrouping these, no matter if they're country-specific or not, would be worth it, for the sake of archiving interesting information within one single (or a series of thread). This thread is aimed at prospecting beginners.

>Why should I live abroad ?
Many reasons. Cost of life can be better abroad, job opportunities more favorable to your field of work, a society you're more in tune with (safety, values). Other possibilities include doing an academic exchange or a double diploma, maybe an internship of some kind that will enhance your CV to prospective recruiters from your home country (or the one you want to go to.)

>But I don't want to live there forever !
It's fine, most people don't and leave after a few years. You don't have to marry a local, buy a house and stay there forever. Sometimes it's nice to go out there, take it out of your system, then come back all grown up and with some new tricks up your sleeve.

posts.name: Tolstoi
posts.com:
>What do you mean by that ? What do I gain from doing a temporary expatriation?
It really depends on how fruitful it was, but aside from whatever professional experience you've gain from it, by doing you so you have learned to leave your comfort zone, forced yourself into socializing with people who had no reason to talk to you besides speaking English and probably befriended some, negotiated for jobs and deals with people that are completely foreign to you and learned what it truly meant to be alone and be your own island, sometimes. If you came to say, Asia, with nothing more than a high school degree and nothing else but your hands, you've also learned how to network, find a job, and to pay your bills you actually had to learn how to keep that job. Of course, perhaps the conditions that made you get the job in the first place won't be there at home, which will make you stay. But at least you're actually functional now. And you'll be able to figure something out.

>Is immigration/expatriation something I should prepare ?
The more you prepare it, the better. Learning the local language (not necessarily bilingual but every bit helps), acquiring a skill, gathering information on how to get in and what visa schemes are available for you are all too important parts of a successful experience abroad.

>why the tripcode ?
Because I won't LARP. The answer you will receive from me will either be something I know to be true from personal experience. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2391118
>>2391118
People always say it's the best way but the way it happens makes it so that it basically never does. MNCs function in such a way that every national branch is its own company. They bill shit to each other, and either compete with, or work in fields that aren't quite the ones back home.

For example, a lot of MNCs will have folks working sales abroad to sell the products produced back home. And the people they will hire are obviously locals because they might be cheaper or just more at ease with communicating with the locals. Also, hiring an equivalent foreign worker is pound to pound as skilled as a local is considered bad practice and is starting to get heavily curbed in Asia.

Therefore, differentiation is key. Differentiation through diplomas (Prestigious ones), differentiation through specialization (PhDs in certain fields of expertise that are needed there, for example, or at least +5 year in a field but more is better).

If you're ballsy enough you can point out a certain need in a foreign branch, explain how to fill it so they can tailor a job offer for you there, too.
This being said, a lot of people manage to get to work abroad if they have +5 years exp in dev, sometimes less. Foreign internships, exchanges and double diplomas during your studies can help if you take the necessary steps professionally to make it work.

In a nutshell, anything that makes you a better person than a local works. And that also goes by evening the playing fields. Some countries have visa schemes that facilitate foreign hiring for skilled workers. Speaking the local language in a professional capacity also helps leveling the playing field and beating other foreign contenders. Again, you don't necessarily need to do all that to try your luck. But I suggest you orient yourself by tailoring yourself to be a competitive foreign worker as you go, which will only better your odds. Also, seriously, the field. Don't go to china with a pol sci degree.

I believe in the material, meat and potatoes. I am interested in the things that I know will bring me happiness. Call me a hedonist if you want, but I refuse to do things that will, further down the line, only bring me depression, contempt for other people, and spend my precious life on this earth.
If there is a more gratifying job, a better partner to be with, a better place to be in, i'll go right there and I see no reason to deprive myself of anything that could be a step up. An argument can be made about what makes it truly a step-up, sure, but it is undeniable that for some people in certain countries, you can really improve your life by going abroad. I actually believe that a temporary experience (which is what an expatriation is, by the way) is nice to have. Discovering foreign cultures in an in-depth way is a life-changing experience and it doesn't have to be a permanent one.

Also, just because you have less value in your country doesn't mean that this value is inherent to you. Maybe being an introverted engineer in a western country that has abandoned its industrial sector translates to being a polite, at ease socially engineer in Taiwan's booming industry ? Maybe being a French chef in France is hardly well paid and recognized because we've got so many of them, but it translates to being a great chef abroad with very interesting and classy recipes ?
In other words, why should an Eskimo who failed at selling popsicles in Alaska be called a failure because he decided to try his luck in Malaysia where the weather's too fucking hot all year around ?
People who think like this are so deep in sunk cost fallacy they can see the Mariana Trench from there. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2395192
>I thought increasingly in asia you require a degree level in whatever to qualify for English teaching at least I thought that was the case in China and Japan.
That is increasingly, and indeed, nearly always the case, and not just in China and Japan. Thailand requires degrees too, has done for years now.

People without degrees but with certifications can still sometimes find work in Thailand, typically either as private tutors or at the sleaziest of private language school sweatshops, but they can’t get work permits or non-immigrant visa sponsorship. So the work (and as often as not, the teachers’ residence) is under the table and officially illegal, with all the risk that implies. It’s been a few years since the last crackdown, but Thai authorities have caught and mass deported English teachers working without proper papers several times that I can remember.

The only place I’ve ever personally known someone to work full-time as a teacher without a degree was Cambodia, but there may be other Wild West possibilities out there.

Still almost certain to run into visa/permit problems, though.

- Saturday: Fly

Rome:
- Sunday: Pantheon, 4 Rivers Fountain, Santa Maria in Vallicella, Trevi Fountain, San Luigi dei Francesi, The Church Of S. M. Sopra Minerva, Santa Maria sopra Minerva

- Monday: Colosseum, Roman Forum, St. John Lateran, San Pietro in Vincoli, Victor Emmanuel II Monument, Capitoline Museum, Basilica San Clemente, San Giuseppe dei Falegnami, Saint Mary Major

- Tuesday: Vatican — St. Peter’s (climb dome), Vatican Museums

- Wednesday: Galleria Borghese, Santa Maria del Popolo, Santa Maria della Vittoria, Spanish Steps, Twin Churches

Pompeii & Naples:
- Thursday: Pompeii, Vesuvius Hike, Piazza Plebiscito (Basillica and Royal Palace), Capella Sansevero

Florence:
- Friday: Galleria dell'Accademia, Duomo (w/ dome), Piazza della Signoria, Ponte Vecchio, Uffizi, Santa Croce (Would also like to see Donatello’s David but probably not practical…)

Venice:
- Saturday: St. Mark’s Square, St. Marks Basilica, Doge’s Palace

- Sunday: Fly

Should I do 2 days in Florence and shove days 1 and 4 together in Rome? Any other suggestions for places to visit (or to not visit) or just general tips? Thanks

not that guy but i also like verona
one problem with italian tourist destinations is that the tourists attract people trying to make money off the tourists - not just cheap companies that dont care about their reputation but also gypsies and illegal immigrants wanting to sell you something for a euro(if you're lucky), but verona compared to the most famous cities in italy, is a little more chill in this regard but there is still the presence. infront of the main sights and shopping streets is obviously where it is most occuring, so side streets or non tourist spots are cool.
very comfy walkable city great architecture - every city has core streets that accumulate the most tourists but it is quite easy to find nice places to wander that are not overly crowded - i went in peak august holidays so maybe local italians were more inclined to be outside the city at the lakes/mountains/beaches.
there are not really famous museums compared to other cities. the core of the city has remnants of roman to medieval to renaissance to Napoleonic structures. surrounding the city are city walls with comfy grass/park areas aorund. but its also a medium sized city so it has young people who are trying modern service businesses in addition to the classic stuff - but also like every region in italy there are local specialties that are nice.

there is the roman amphitheatre in the middle of town
the old castle you can walk through but it has a museum
the large gardens on the hill above the river
Juliet's Balcony is the only tourist trap (there is no historical juliet..), but if you have a girl to impress it can be useful

but just like getting a gelato next to the river or chilling at a restaurant on the river bank are what i liked about it.

I am flying from Prague to Italy on the 17th of April, need to fly out of Bologna on the 26th.

Have thought of two different itineraries:

Fly into Pisa and train to Cinque Terre for a couple of nights, before making my way to Florence, spending 4-5 nights there or potentially a couple in Siena, and finishing in Bologna. This requires backtracking between Cinque Terre and Pisa.

or

Flying to Venice and spending a night or two there, take the train to Verona and spend 1-2 nights there, and then to Florence with a day trip or two to Tuscan countryside. End in Bologna. This does require backtracking as Bologna is between Verona and Florence but it's only an extra 40 minutes on high speed rail.

Travelling with my girlfriend, decent budget for daily expenses and hotels.

Basically tossing up between Cinque Terre and more time in Florence/Tuscany vs Venice/Verona and a bit less time in Florence.

I'll just say that Bologna is really expensive as far as Italy goes and the city isn't all that interesting, I spent 3-4 days there and would have removed it from my itinerary if I were to do the trip again. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2390375
I agree with the others saying that Napoli is too far out of the way to make sense, which is tough to say because I loved it there.
For Rome, I highly recommend a bit in the southern end of the city. Before the Colosseum, take the metro down to the Piramide station, right outside theres an awesome Roman early Imperial era pyramid that was incorporated into the city walls. Then a short walk away is Caracalla's baths which really shows massive Roman imperial architecture and life. Then a short walk past the circus maximus you get to the Colosseum area. Far more impressive than the overrated spanish steps and the like, but a fraction of the crowds.
If you have a bit more time in Rome, the Park of the Aqueducts is scenic and a bit awe inspiring, it's right near the Lucio Sestio metro station. That neighborhood is also a chill and modern area to see the new city.
Elsewhere in Rome, Ponte Palatino and the nearby transtiberium neighborhood is cool.
One busy day in Florence was enough for me personally. I planned on spending longer, but wanted to get out so took day trips out. Siena was one of my favorites.
Sounds like a good trip, enjoy!

Excellent itinerary. I'd recommend flying into Venice if you can, spend a couple of days there, and then start moving southernly, so you're not bouncing back and forth. I used the water taxi as a cheap boat tour of the Venice, which was pretty cool. Also a great thing to do at night is this ceviche tour where you get taken to various trattorias and pubs for a specialized appetizer and a matched wine. It was a unique experience and a lot of fun.

The Catacombs in Rome are a must-see imo

Toward the end of my trip, in Naples, I took the ferry for Ischia for a day and a night. On Ischia they have this centuries-old water park of about 50 volcanically-heated mineral pools, all of different temperatures, with a nice cafe at the top of the mountain and a private beach at the bottom. That was a nice way to unwind after a pretty hectic few weeks of sightseeing.

>>2393652
This.

One of my best friends was in the Peace Corps. He was actually stationed in central Zanzibar for about 3 years. I visited him for a few months in 2017. The interior of the island is largely comprised of impoverished villages. There isn’t much to do or see. However, visiting isn’t unsafe. Small children might ask you for money (or throw stones at you). If you can speak Swahili, they’ll treat you like a human. Otherwise, you’re a walking money dispenser.

I spent my birthday there and rented a motorcycle for a few days. Riding around Zanzibar was fun, although the drivers are the worst I’ve ever seen (and I say that as someone who now lives in India).

TBQH it’s a pleasant place to spend a few days, but there isn’t much to do outside of Stone Town and the popular beaches. It’s also all-around pretty safe, but armed robberies sometimes happen after sunset on isolated stretches of beach adjacent to resorts and planned parties.

I work on cruise ships, currently on vacation, my next vacation is in March.

The previous anons talking about fjords are onto something, Alaska, Norway and New Zealand take on a whole different dimension when you see if from the ocean. Those would be the only places I’d visit on a cruise,with the exception of the Greek isles and French Polynesia. Everywhere else is better on land or not worth visiting.

Small towns can be alright, but sometimes the cruise planners are filling in random ports so they can sell it as unique, this particularly true in places like South/central America and Africa that essentially are industrial ports and require excursions to actually see anything. Also if it’s really small the ship might not actually dock but anchor, and tendering is a shitty experience, I’m glad they pay me to put up with it.

If you wanna enjoy activities the actual ship, go with big (4,500 passengers +) and book a week wherever is cheap/ convenient for you. Anything smaller than 3000 guests is gonna be on the «quieter « side.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2395621
>>2395621
Pretty much this, it’s all about immersion. Switch your devices over to Spanish (you don’t have to download a keyboard, just can set the proprietary keyboard to switch between whatever languages you need). The only app I really used was conjugation nation, which has a finite number of tenses and verbs, but it compliments learning grammar well.

you can listen to podcasts and watch content based around slanish-learning, but after about 3-4 months you’re gonna wanna switch to content targeting native speakers. Netflix has commissioned a lot of spanish language series due the success of La casa de papel/money heist, and my teachers always insisted to NOT use any subtitles. The point of watching that kind of content isn’t to practice reading lines, it’s to understand context, phrasing, colloquialisms and conversational flow.

I also subscribed to new channels on YouTube like el pais and bbc mondo. I listen to a shitload of music with spanish lyrics, not only does it help with vocabulary, but native speaking’s think it’s crazy when you can recite the lyrics to a banda song or even know about a group like hombres G. If you like sports watch La liga and NFL offers Highlights in Mexican spanish.

I went from tourist levels to nearly fluent (for you euros A2 to B2/C1) in about 9 months, but that involved 6 months of intensive lessons in Spain/Colombia. If anybody decides to go that route DO NOT fall back to hanging out with your classmates and speaking English. You will go nowhere and forget everything the moment you go home.

I live 10 minutes from MIA

The only decent neighborhood near the airport is where I live, Coral Gables. It's mostly wealthy South Americans with a nice little shopping area called the Miracle Mile. Couple bars and a bunch of restaurants. If you're looking to party, it's not the place to go. It's just quiet and chill over here.

Everything else anywhere near the airport is a dump. Nothing but trash Cubans. Shitty drivers and terrible people. Good Latin food though if you really want it.

If you want nice beaches, I'd recommend going north. Anything around Ft. Lauderdale will be ok. South Beach is beautiful, but unless you get out there early, parking is nonexistent and the whole area is over run with darkie tourists shooting and robbing each other.

If you want to hang out at shitty overpriced bars Wynwood is fun for out of towners.

Like the other guy said, if you have any interest in nature, the Everglades are incredible.

Oh, and the whole state is flooded with Jews and Northerners right now so traffic is god awful and they all bring their dumb shit with them.

Depending on what you're looking for, Miami isn't that bad, even with how much I'm bitching about it. If you let me know what kind of stuff you're looking for I'm more than happy to offer recommendations.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2389542
Wrote a whole post and then the browser refreshed and I lost it. Fark.
Basically, i'm on a 3 month Eurotrip and packed more than I needed despite going through freezing temps, snow, rain, heat, wind.
My tips for you are:
Realise you're going to be wearing the same clothes more often than you think. Same socks for 3 days, same shirt for 5 days, same pants for 2 weeks, etc.
Anti-perspirant is your friend as it'll stop you stinking up your clothes after you've only worn them for a day.
Every city is going to have a laundromat so the chances of you getting stuck with no clothes to wear is unlikely. If you're overly paranoid though or travelling somewhere you doubt there will be laundromats, pack a clothes washing soap bar.
Depending on where you're going all you really need is 1 scenario-specific outfit (by that I mean a "going out" outfit or a "hiking" outfit) and even then, try and fit that with your everyday outfit. For example, a "going out" outfit might just be your everyday jeans with a nice shirt rather than bringing nice jeans and a nice shirt. If you're going hiking your everyday shirt will be fine and more often than not, so will your everyday jeans.

Of course if you're a woman you're probably going full wacko mode and you're going to pack shit you don't need regardless. My gf has done this but even she recognises she's packed too much and has "nicer" clothes that she's hardly worn because at the end of the day when you're travelling and you're tired of catching buses and trains all day and it's freezing cold and you're hungry, you don't give a fuck about what you're wearing you just want to be comfortable.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2390406
Merino wool are top tier as base layers for hikes and mountaineering. Also comfy as shit as general winter baselayers like longjohns and long-sleeved undershirts in cold climates.
Wool is very warm as it creates many insulating air layers next to your skin. Critically, it's one of few materials that will keep trapping heat even when wet, hence the popularity as a base layer. It is terrible against wind though, a cotton tshirt will block more windchill than a $50 wool undershirt so you need another layer.

I suppose it's practical for the purposes you wrote as well but if you plan on wearing it instead of a t-shirt day to day you'll probably get pretty warm when indoors.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2390409
But if you plan to do hiking you should at least avoid cotton since, as you know, cotton shirts gets soaked and cold when wet. In colder climates this means that you'd have to change the shirt whenever you break to avoid getting cold (which is absolutely doable). You can avoid that discomfort with a woolen baselayer though. For warmer climates sticky wet cotton shirts are still uncomfortable so I'd prefer a in part synthetic work-out shirt.

>>2391474 (OP)
Moroccanfag here.
Morocco, and muslim countries in general, tend to give foreigners a lot of leeway because they understand the culture is different. They have millions of tourists coming every year, especially during the summer, and the ties with france and spain are particularly strong, historically, diplomatically and culturally too. The only thing they're not okay with is what they perceive to be obvious marks of disrespect. No faux pas will actually be taken personally by most locals. Morocco is the most liberal arab country there is.

In terms of public displays of affection, everything short of kissing is fine. You can hug your gf, hold her hands, etc. It's ok to talk to women, and since you're with your gf i'm guessing you're not going to be flirting anyway so it should be fine. To be perfectly honest, if you kissed, there wouldn't be a lynching either. A local would just call you out and that's it.

>what small things that aren't a big deal for us are frowned upon?
pretty much nothing. Except maybe one : there are liquor stores all over the place, and they usually sell you stuff in black bags or shit like that. Don't show alcohol on you. Also, a big hallmark of a tourist restaurant with high markups is that they sell alcohol. If a restaurant sells alcohol, i guarantee you'll see only foreigners in there.

BTW, don't have any pity towards the panhandlers, especially the pushy ones or the kids. They earn a lot of fucking money while the guys doing the real jobs don't get none and then they take that money to their parents who are basically pimping them out. Please don't perpetuate this.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2389863
In short, if youre not a moron you'll be fine. Most if not all transportation methods have English signage and audio announcements. Traveling around will be no problem. Not all but a lot of restaurants have pictures of the plate so you can point and say "kore, kudasai", some will even have English menus that will be given to you if you don't look japanese.
You should get a translator for sure. Example the first time I went to Japan I saw a old wooden sign by a creek, took a pic, and translated it. It said "Don't fish the fish, keep the river clean, please." And you can do the same with menus in places that don't have pics or English.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2392612
i'll answer this since i solo travel frequently for work and staff debacles are my biggest nightmare. scope the place out first either in person or online. If it has a ticket machine out front, no problem. insert money, click food button, take ticket, click change button and take change. Then you just hand your ticket to the staff, 0 words needed. Picture menus are a bit more dicey, as you might get follow up questions about how you want your noodles, etc. I was there in November and some places in major cities even have tablet ordering now w language support. Just take 5min to do some groundwork before meals and you'll be okay.

>Is it actually a good city to live in?

As someone who actually just got done scratching it off my list of possible places to move to, IMO not really.

Pro's:
>low housing costs
>spread out enough to not be too cramped
>all four seasons
>fairly broad job infrastructure
>highway can get you around quickly
>fairly low cost of living compared to other places
Con's
>low pay without maintaining a gov job, healthcare, or remote job
>old houses will all but require some renovations or pay out the ass for something new
>car basically required, not the worst but winter can make a bike/motorcycle useless with how shit the roads get
>downtown is pretty grabage and in the middle of another migration COVID did a number on it
>job market is far more susceptible to recessions

If you can basically buy a house out right you should be okay, just know that the job market is pretty meh depending on the sector you work in

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2386906
Rural Colombia is indeed gorgeous in many spots, and Costa Rica has some of the most beautiful concentrated nature I’ve ever seen anywhere, while being safer and easier to get around (although Colombia is mostly safer than its reputation nowadays too). Urban Colombia, however, despite a bit of grit and risk in some spots, is far more charming than urban Costa Rica—San Jose, through which you will have to pass, is an ugly shithole, and while nearly every other town in the country is somewhat more attractive they’re small and have limited historical or cultural interest, apart from Cartago, which has an OK little colonial center.

All that said, the food isn’t particularly good in either country IMO. There are a few local specialties that are worth eating once or twice, but I would say that both Colombian and Costa Rican cooking tend toward the heavy, greasy, and bland.

Mexico or especially Thailand are both far better places to eat as far as I’m concerned. I don’t know Puerto Vallarta specifically, but Mexican beaches I have visited in the Yucatán and Riviera Maya can be very nice if a bit resort/package tourism dominated.

I know Thailand very well—lived there for years—and will always love the place, but I encourage most people to go somewhere other than Bangkok first and see BKK on the way out. I love the place in a lot of ways but love almost everywhere else in the country more. It’s hot, smoggy, has miserable traffic, and isn’t especially attractive, so it can make a bad first impression, but it undeniably has a great deal going on. There are as many favorite beaches there as there are people, but I’ve had great times on Ko Samui (easy mode, avoid Chaweng Beach, which is sleazy and grubby); Phuket (even easier mode, avoid Patong Beach, which is sleazy and grubby and Russian Mafia, I like the southern tip of the island); Ko Chang (no airport so takes a bit longer to reach, mix of hippies and smaller resorts); and others.

>>2389185
The best way is to just not do it. Tell your GP before you go on the trip that you're going on a trip, and you need your prescription for the entire duration of the trip. Add one month or something (depends on the lenght of your trip) to make sure that even if you get delayed for whatever reason you're not left without your presciption.
There are ofc variables, like the majority of the world has cheaper meds than the USA. And also some meds are extremely illegal in some countries, so look it all up. Based on the main ingredient, not the brand name.
In some third world countries your solution might work great, and you might get what you need, for cheaper, too. But let's say you go to any Western country or any country with laws, their GPs will not care too much about your home prescription, they will want to do their own checks, and you might end up with some completely different meds than what you are used to. The only reason to bring your home prescription is in case customs wants to check why you have certain meds.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2389484
I actually agree with all of your advice here, but
> go to any Western country or any country with laws, their GPs will not care too much about your home prescription, they will want to do their own checks, and you might end up with some completely different meds than what you are used to.

Isn’t necessarily true in my experience. A lot of European cities have walk-in travel clinics for foreigners that can sometimes fill prescriptions for visitors based on a foreign script, with relatively few questions asked. My wife accidentally ran out of thyroid meds while on holiday in Portugal once and was able to get what she needed from a clinic just by showing them the empty box with her name on the prescription label. And when I moved countries, I was able to get an armload of prescriptions from my new GP just by telling him the medications I needed (I have multiple chronic health conditions). That last case is different, of course, because it was implicit that I would have some kind of ongoing relationship with the doctor and he would eventually see blood work for me.

But assuming the medications involved aren’t dangerous or tightly controlled (probably wouldn’t work for anything psychoactive, definitely wouldn’t work for narcotics), it is often possible to get an emergency script from a foreign doctor in the west.

Still agree that the best option is to get a “vacation fill” of whatever you’re on to last as long as you will be away whenever possible, though.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I hate flying, going to be flying in a month from california to london, what's a drug that's guaranteed to knock me out cold the whole time? I'm awake at night a month ahead thinking about this flight, it's driving me crazy with anxiety. I want to try a few different medications before i go.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2391230
Ambien or another high-test hypnotic sleeping pill might do the trick. If you’re not concerned about potential abuse and addiction, you might also talk to a doctor about a small quantity of an anxiolytic like Xanax or Ativan, but any drug in the barbiturate or benzodiazepine families is more serious business than people like to think, and shouldn’t be used too casually. They’re all physically habit-forming with nasty withdrawal symptoms, and some people get unpleasant benzo hangovers that can leave you groggy and stupid for an extended period. They can, however, ameliorate anxiety symptoms very effectively in the short term, even if they don’t necessarily render you unconscious.

You should also think about jet lag—I agree with those experts who say that you should avoid trying to sleep at times when you wouldn’t be asleep at your destination while in transit. But it’s virtually impossible to do this perfectly, so if you need to conk out to survive a flight it’s not the end of the world even if it’s suboptimal.

If they haven’t already by the time I finish typing this, someone will surely suggest combining alcohol with one or more of the above. It might work, but I think it’s à fundamentally dumb idea—while alcohol can be good for making you pass out, it’s terrible for sleep quality, so it will make you less likely to stay asleep, and you’re likely to wake up unrested with a hangover in the middle of your flight.

I recommend looking up some anti-anxiety breathing exercises and guided meditation—it may sound like bullshit but in my experience as an anxious person it can also actually work.

I appreciate the advice, i need to go see a doctor ASAP

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2391241
Oh, and if you do end up going with a sleeping pill like Ambien or Lunesta, try it at home a few days before you fly to see how long it lasts in your case, so you can time your dosing appropriately. You will not enjoy dragging your ass through customs and immigration while still deeply under the influence of one of these drugs, nor do you want to still be comatose when you land.

Another psychoactive medication you might want to discuss with your doctor is trazodone; it’s an ancient antidepressant, but it also has some anti-anxiety and sedative properties and used to get prescribed for insomnia. I use a small dose daily at bedtime as part of a depression and anxiety regimen, and while I can’t say it knocks me out for ten hours, it does make me sleepy and I wake up more relaxed.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2391732
>Any tips on motion sickness pills? Never had them
Many of the OTC ones are based on dimenhydrinate; seems to work OK for my kids. Can make you a bit sleepy but not enough to be used as a sedative. It’s a dissociative/quasi-hallucinogen in the case of massive overdose or deliberate abuse by bored teenagers. Don’t drink alcohol while taking it, less for side effects and more because it seems to stop it from working almost completely.

You can also get scopolamine pills or patches, although these may be script-only depending on where you live; my uncle, who liked deep sea fishing but could also barf walking through a puddle, depended on these.

Another Rx-only drug that in my limited experience might be the most powerful is Ondansetron, AKA Zofran, which can even keep chemotherapy patients from upchucking. My wife got it once in the ER when she had debilitating nausea and she stopped throwing up in seconds, although she had it as an injection rather than a tablet. Not sure if it’s given often for self-administration.

Copper-alloy wristbands and similar talismans work only if you are highly responsive to placebo effects.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2395522
Virgin Atlantic has fucked up pricing mostly because it had more difficulty with covid as it is a smaller airline. It declared bankruptcy because of covid (not a going out of business bankruptcy, a restructure/refinance bankruptcy) and is still not doing well. Delta almost owns half the company, operates a bunch of its flights, and Virgin Atlantic is joining Delta's alliance. Prices will probably settle down to standard variability this or next year, but smaller airlines all have more (as a percentage, not total number) weird situations such as you described than larger airlines.

posts.com:
>>2378143
You're wrong. You can get a room in Seville for like $400 a month, I know someone who is doing this. It's a nice college town, young sluts come from all over Europe on Erasmus.

If a Latino immigrant making 10€/hr picking strawberries can make it in Spain, you can too, ffs. You could get a room in a tier-one city like Madrid for like 700 bucks.

You just have to know where to look for an apartment. Don't use AirBnb for anything other than the short term. Go on local Facebook groups and ask where to get started looking.

If people find out you have a remote American income they'll be lining up to rent to you. I met a Brazilian guy willing to rent to me for $40 a night at the height of the tourist season in Barcelona. If you looked online you'd hardly be able to find anything for less than $200, if you were able to find anything at all. Wasn't a bad part of town either, even though in Spain "the bad part of town" is an absolute joke in terms of danger compared to the US, Latin America, France, etc.

You do have to be aware of scams. If a nigger starts video calling you asking for a deposit on a place you haven't been to, don't give him anything.

I've found that Spain is a nice middle ground for someone looking to live large on a remote income. It's a safe, clean white country that is full of attractive women, very cosmopolitan with a vast cultural wealth at the same time. The nightlife is out of this world. I was able to eat out twice a day and get drunk every night when I went, and I make less than $100k. Yes, it's difficult if you depend on the local economy to make a living, but if you make your money abroad it's an option that is definitely worth considering.

It goes without saying that social circles will be the key to having a good life there like anywhere else. The Tinder scene is just as brutal as in America. If you're looking for a place that isn't as expensive as the US you're better off going to Spain.

I work for a major, international corporate entity.

I work from home, however, I use extremely specific software and rely on a data interface which is tightly relegated to my work laptop which they have provided me with.

To log on to my work laptop, I have to log in through a company VPN, which of course exposes my location.

My company is extremely anal about security. I have a cunt of a line manager, which makes it near impossible for me to raise the question of working abroad with her. I know she’ll get uppity and cause problems; the main reason being that if I have technical issues with my laptop, which happens often due to the precarious nature of our software, I’m required to go to my place of work and get the IT team to take a look.

My question is this. If I use 5g on my mobile, using my home SIM on international roaming, and use that to hotspot my laptop, would they be able to tell my true location?

The reason I ask is that whenever I use my sim abroad, I find that I’m still using my home countries internet services. Google is in English, my advertisements are all in England and the same that I get at home. It’s not until I connect to local WiFi that I get foreign ads etc.

Anyone got any advice?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2390824
>My question is this. If I use 5g on my mobile, using my home SIM on international roaming, and use that to hotspot my laptop, would they be able to tell my true location?
I'd say 98% yes - the remote IP address they'll see you connecting from will be an IP address belonging to the foreign telco provider. It won't be one of the IP addresses of your home telco provider.
The 2% chance I'm holding back is because I'm aware some telcos do have the options of SIMs with fixed IP addresses tied to them. Without knowing where you are from and what telco you use, I've gotta put that chance as low.
>The reason I ask is that whenever I use my sim abroad, I find that I’m still using my home countries internet services. Google is in English, my advertisements are all in England and the same that I get at home. It’s not until I connect to local WiFi that I get foreign ads etc.
I wouldn't put too much weight on this, but you could tell pretty easily by visiting whatsmyip.com while using your SIM abroad and seeing what it says.

There are ways you can get around having a foreign IP address. Others have probably talked about them already, but they come down to using a router or gateway device that can use a VPN. On that device you'd use a VPN (preferably to a friend's home network in your home country, but maybe ExpressVPN will work for you since many of their exit nodes are partnered with local ISPs). Then you connect your work laptop to that router/gateway device. Your work laptop connects to the company VPN and your company VPN sees it coming from the personal/ExpressVPN address your router/gateway is using. If you do this route, you need a router/gateway that with a killswitch that will completely drop your internet interface if the VPN drops.
I think your big problem is having flaky work software that require you to bring the laptop to the office to fix. Maybe get a second work laptop for your "month at the cottage"?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2390824
>If I use 5g on my mobile, using my home SIM on international roaming, and use that to hotspot my laptop, would they be able to tell my true location?
Yeah, they would. International roaming depends on your carrier's agreement with some local carrier to provide you service in order to work. So when you try to log in, it'll show that country's location.

And it's not a guarantee you'll be able to get 5G wherever you go. Even in Europe. I paid my American carrier for unlimited roaming internet while abroad (again, it was a French carrier providing me the actual service, you can only do this a few months before they cut you off anyway), and I bought a French SIM card, and even then, the best I could get was 4G.

Besides that, if your company really is anal about security then there's no way in hell you'll be able to hide the fact that you're abroad from them. The fact that you would even ask this means you aren't technically sophisticated enough to outwit your IT department. You'd only end up getting yourself in trouble.

My advice would be that, if working abroad means that much to you (and I can understand that, because it's a life-changing perk) then I would suggest you look for a job with a company that's willing to look the other way. This means banks and security work are probably a no-go for you (though there are surely exceptions). You should be looking for a new job constantly anyway, so that your compensation is as high as it can be.

Many companies won't allow you to work from abroad, if only to save themselves the tax and legal troubles they would have to figure out in another country. But if you use an American mailing address (say, your parents') and give them plausible deniability, many companies are willing to look the other way to keep valuable employees, including mine.

Brazil has about 50k murders per year. That said, most murders are related to drug/gang problems and take place in poor neighborhoods that you should not go as a foreigner. so it's not likely.
The problem is robbery. Sometimes people get shot by the robber, whether because they tried to react and failed or just because the criminal felt like killing the victim. That's what you should be afraid as a foreigner.

I was robbed once. I'm 30 yo and weekly got drunk and waited late night in the street for my uber to arrive, though. So, statistically speaking, it's very unlikely for a foreigner that spends a few weeks here to be robbed.
But yes, it can happen and compared to european cities brazilian cities are very dangerous. Don't think that's enough to make you decide not to travel here, though.
Just don't wear jewelry, waches, don't flash cash and use your phone in a discreet manner.
Is Brazil a good option to just chill, where you can simply go as you wish without putting yourself into danger? No, there are much better places; even in poor countries.
But you will be fine if you're not stupid and you're travelling as a single man or in a small group of friends. Brazilians naturally develop some kind of street smart but you should be fine if you're not clueless and act like if you were in Norway.
Also, stay in hotels or rent Airbnbs in apartment buildings or houses in gated communities. Do not rent regular houses. Even though the risk of something happening is not that high, better not to gamble with it.

Rio and SP have lots of motorcycle robberies. And traffick really sucks. Easy to park, though.
>>2393406
Nowadays in Rio and SP a cheap meal will cost you 50 reais, a good one about 100-120 up to few hundred reais. Mcdonalds would cost about 40 reais.
A 330ml heineken bottle in a market will cost you about 5, 10 in a cheap bar, 15 in a expensive bar. In expensive nightclubs 2-3x that. A black label whisky shot about 40.
An uber ride for 5km will cost you about 25-30 reais. A subway ticket is about 5 reais in SP, the same price of a bus.
Locals are very friendly towards foreigners. No one will target you for being american. You could get hustled to buy something from street vendors, specially in Rio, for a higher price. But that's pretty much it.
In southern regions I recommend Iguazu Falls (3 days is enough) for nature (much better than shitty niagara falls) and Florianopolis to chill on the beach and party. In the state of SP there is Ilhabela. In the state of Minas Gerais, there ae some nice colonial towns like Ouro Preto and Tiradentes (just to spend a full day in each). In the state of Rio de Janeiro, Angra dos Reis (if you have money to charter a boat; there are more than 1000 beaches and 360 islands) and Paraty (also a colonial town and boat related stuff).
In northeastern region there are lots of beach resorts. If you want to see the most african city in Brazil and our first capital, go to Salvador. Besides that, I only recommend Lençois Maranhenses.
In northern region Manaus (2 days at most) and some jungle resort in the Amazon. Also there is Jalapão.
In center west region, there is Pantanal, a wetland. Not much to do besides seeing animals and flora.
Cooming is good. Better if you are in good shape, specially in Rio. And greater if you're white, tall, blond, blue eyed.
Brazilian women are easy and attracted to foreigners. Hookers (from good places) provide a girlfriend experience.

>>2393841
Try feijoada, pastel, coxinha, comida de boteco (bar food), rodizio (all you can eat meat)...
The country is huge so depends of where you going. But I would say the best months in southeastern states are april-june and september-november. Not too hot or cold and not too much rain. In São Paulo it can get near 0 C, but usually 5-10C in cold winter days and 35C in hot summer days. Rio get 15C in cold days and 40+C in hot summer days. Bear in mind that 10C in Brazil is much colder than 3C in European countries. We usually do not have heating inside houses and shops so it does feel cold.
I just advise to rent a car if you want to travel to smaller cities like from SP to southern MG and Paraty. Inside cities just use uber/taxi. If you go from capital to capital just fly.
Not really sure about hotels. Like anywhere else I just look for the ratings, location and hotel class. You won't have a problem booking 4+ stars hotels. If you're looking for cheap places, take care. We have motels (love hotels) that are used for having sex and places that attract low level scum to use drugs. So just book good places. 50-100 usd gets you great places in most cities and 100-200 usd gets you 5 star hotels in the expensive cities.
About the water, it depends of the state you are. I have friends that drink tap water. I do not, even though it seems that the water where I live is good for drinking. I would advise you to buy water instead. In Rio you definetely would not want to drink from the tap.

Neuquen is pretty much a big city now, isn't really that isolated, and has great landscapes.

Chubut and Santa Cruz are pretty much full of industries and huge distances between every landmark. Would recommend it if you like isolation, snow and driving in it.

Argie here, I'm seeing a handful of misconceptions about this place and the surrounding countries, so I'll clarify a couple things. Feel free to ask about anything else you have doubts about.

For one, this is not a "globohomo-free" country. Quite the opposite, in fact. Save for Uruguay, this is the most pozzed country in latin america. The government is more preoccuppied with preventing "hateful discourse" and forcing a butchered "inclusive" version of the spanish language than taking care of the one half of our population who's living below the poverty line. Not to mention most sides of the political spectrum haven't necessarily adopted but have at least accepted and allowed this shit to happen.
A second thing to note, I have no idea why you'd want to live in a country that has been edging at the brink of economic collapse for decades. Unless you feel like Lord Miles wasn't enough of a retard, I see no reason to leave your home to come live in a place like this. Also, you better like taxes, because you're gonna see a lot of them.
As for the surrounding countries, Uruguay has a great quality of life and everything outside Montevideo is fucking empty. Paraguay and Bolivia are alright, they're somehow less corrupt and more stable than we are. Chile is good, they recently elected a leftie, so people are panicking about them going the way of Venezuela and yours truly, but if you ask me, he seems like a very down-to-earth guy when compared to the usual, blind, retarded ideologues every other country gets when they elect a left-wing politician.

Ask away if you wanna know anything about the people, climate, living standards, etc. of any particular province/region.

Yup, government sponsored, too.

Back in the day when the country got its independence, our caudillos (pretty much spanish for "warlord") raided the south and genocided the shit out of every native tribes they could find. Somehow, this one survived and ended up becoming a what's essentially a cold war-style left-wing guerrilla terrorist group.

Once every few weeks, you'll hear of them terrorizing the people living in and around Neuquén, Río Negro, Chubut, and rarely Santa Cruz and southern Mendoza. They're always fighting with locals and "reclaiming" land belonging to the mapuche nation (look up "wallmapu" to see the extent of their larp).
The government, being your typical, run-of-the-mill leftie activist group, loves turning a blind eye to it. The last bit of news I remember hearing about is them intervening to take land away from the army to give it to one of these groups and the ensuing shitstorm that followed. Last year they spent like a whole month raiding the town of El Bolsón, to the point the locals got tired of nobody doing shit and took it in their own hands to literally ride on horses and hunt them down cowboy style. It was pretty surreal.

That said, it's not unlivable. Many popular tourist destinations are smack-dab in the middle of mapuche territory. Their numbers are far smaller here than in Chile, so the real problem lies on the other side of the Andes, it's just that here they have free reign to fuck with people.
If you see pic related, stay wary.

For culture Buenos Aires has one of the nicest concert halls in the Americas for classical music but the big stars like Daniel Barenboim do not live there. There are a few art museums. The military museum is also fun. La recoleta and la chacarita cemeteries to see the perons and gardel.

Eat pizza empanadas steak drink wine and plenty of fernet with coke!

If you go out on a sunday, you'll smell asado coming out of every other house you walk across. There are also restaurants specifically just for eating asado and several kinds of meat, but if you manage to make some friends, you might prefer the "authentic" experience and get it done on some dude's backyard. If you walk around the city, you can sit down just about anywhere and look at the menu. I say milanesa if you're at a restaurant, tostado if you're at a café.
If you're a sweet tooth, walk into a store and get yourself some dulce de leche and alfajores. You'll thank me for the rest of your goddamn life.
If you're into wine, Mendoza is one of the top locations in the world for that stuff. Not much else to add.
