>>2332641
>how's the crime in the smaller cities and towns?
There used to be places here where there wasn't much to fear years ago, but the country is going downhill hard, so those places are starting to feel it.
That said, it will be less common than in the big cities. I won't say anywhere near zero, but it's harder to get away with shit when the place is small and everybody knows each other, lel. Town life is mostly chill, but far poorer depending on where you go (the north especially).
>Let's say a town of about 10k -- is there cartel bullshit going on there, or in any of the countryside?
Doubt it, most of the drug trafficking happens around/in the outskirts of the bigger cities (the exception being Rosario, where the WHOLE city is the argentinian equivalent of a mexican narco state, stay the fuck away).
>Do you feel safer in general in the smaller towns than you do in the cities?
Crime can always happen. You will be more "exposed" in small towns and you might be in trouble if you're hurt badly or feel unsafe at a particular moment in time, because small town hospitals have few resources and not as many policemen, while you'll be more prone to it in the cities but at least there are more resources/people to help you. "Safety" kinda depends on how much you can fend for yourself.
>How are the real estate prices there compared to La Tierra de las Hamburguesas?
Don't know much about that, actually, but I can tell you two things:
-Buenos Aires has been having problems reminiscent to that of London this year. Shit is too expensive and too small, so nobody wants it.
-As for the whole country in general, prices are just going up like everything else, so if you're planning to buy something, make sure you bring in as much foreign currency as you can so you don't have to start collecting Monopoly money that will have both lost its value and fallen short of the new price by the time you have it.

Tons of options, red meat in general is awesome but there's also exceptionally good pizzas and ice cream. You can eat a 4-star meal for less than 10 usd.
As for more traditional foods, you can try locro, empanadas, guiso, and if you like sweet stuff, anything with dulce de leche. Like alfajores or facturas that you can buy in panaderias. Croissants with dulce de leche are a must.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2327930
And about the drinking there's pretty good regional beer, and the last decade breweries have opened everywhere in most cities. IPA, APA, scottish, pale, etc.
I don't personally drink wine, but Argentinian wine is highly regarded as one of the best in the world. I've seen tourists praise even the cheap ones.
Decent whisky, outside of your typical brands
Not much vodka, tequila or rum, even though there is enough variety
And then there is Fernet. Mixed with Coke. Oh boy, it has a strong taste so it's a hit or miss, but if it hits, it's heaven.

If you're wondering about non-añcoholic drinks, meh. I guess we have mate, which is an infusion, sorta like herb tea, served on a wooden bowl (also called mate). It's more of a social thing, people sit together and pass the mate around, while chilling, or eating some snacks.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2385358
Obviously you will not be fluent in 3 months (that is a task for a lifetime) but with 3 months of serious, consistent effort, you can learn the 2000 or so words you need to express basically any non-abstract thought or request.

It won't feel like much beforehand, but I did this exact thing (learn the 2000 most common words and practice listening/speaking every day for an hour for 3 months) before going to Russia, and the way people treat you with even that level of the language is remarkably different than if you are totally helpless. Most importantly, it turns basic things like ordering food or asking directions into an opportunity for an interesting interaction, rather than a tooth-pulling simulation.

And I know this sort of advice does not actually work on a person who becomes anxious:, but regardless: do remember that most tourists have no knowledge of the country's language whatsoever, so literally anything you can say or do in the language puts you far ahead of the average. From your perspective it might seem embarrassing to struggle with the language, but whatever monolingual person you're talking to is probably quite happy you're attempting to accommodate them, and feels no "vicarious embarrassment" for you.

Also, with that base, you can just barely start to have full conversations with people if you have a knack for languages and, believe me, the same country is two entirely different places when you can speak the language (even a little) vs. when you cant.

Transfer parents are shit except they are all part of an Alliance.

I use LifeMiles/Turkish for direct United flights
I use Virgin Atlantic for direct Delta Flights
I use British Airways for direct AA flights

Used 125k Amex points for a EVA airways round trip flight ORD-TPE. Not the best redemption but free $1250 flight.

If you live near a hub (SFO,LAX, ORD, EWR, JFK, MSP) Amex points make a hell of a lot of sense.

You can catch 90k RT business class seats from US -> Europe if you are flexible. You get the serious redemptions booking 330 days out or booking within the last 1-3 weeks.

It's worth it if you're going to use your CC for everything, and I mean EVERYTHING to keep the value of the card worth it.

The biggest drawbacks with these often come from the small fee's that to someone not using it for business and business travel don't make sense.
Yearly fee's can add up

Point Policy changes
If you keep a balance running can be more expensive in TCO

unless you literally plan to long term use this card as a replacement for your others, any decent reward card tends to be just as good. FF programs often pay off better as they have no fee's and still can give upgrades. Pretty much any time I fly AA or their partners I am upgraded due to status.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2393733
Was just in Zagreb two months ago. Extremely comfy city, but was very cold though when I was there. Stay near Jelacic Square, its the center of the city and very cool. The whole city reminds me a lot of the atmosphere of Vampire The Masquerade Bloodlines, has a very gothic and "Dracula" like feel to it, especially in the dark winters and nightime. Eat at and support the old school mom and pop family restaurants where everything tastes home-cooked in large portions, avoid the shitty trend of cringy, wannabe "Instagram" restaurants that place more emphasis on "presentation" than on the food- my filter is if they serve food on a square plate then its going to be absolute trash. The restaurants I liked to eat at were Croation barbeque restaurants known as "Konobas" which are the main local staples of their food. Any place that serves a "Mixed Meat Plate" (which is fucking amazing), Sopska salad (also amazing) and Ajvar sauce (also amazing) is going to be legit. You probably already know this though if you are coming from Slovenia, because its generally the same all over the Balkans. Have fun, I wish I had more time in Zagreb myself, I was only there for 3 days.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com: I would say it is the most overrated. Try and remember that being overrated does not mean it’s terrible or even not good. It means it’s rated higher than it actually is. France is considered like the top or top 3 destinations by a ton of people, and I don’t think it’s that. A lot of this is due to the fact it USED to be that good, but isn’t anymore. Paris is now kind of a dump, it used to be great. Many of the places that were awesome because they were “untouched” are now flooded with tourists. Still a great country for tourism generally speaking but equal to tons of other places in Europe. There are also places that are in fact cheaper and just as good. If it continues its downward spiral it will be in the bottom half of Europe destinations before 2030, but you still hear people talk like it’s still top tier. So yes quite overrated

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Maybe because when people think about France they only think about Paris. Paris may be overrated but it's still undeniably an exceptional city. Some of the best museums in the world, architectural beauty, and in some places you can still sort of imagine the Paris of the 1930s/1950s.
The rest of France offers a lot of variety. High mountains, Atlantic thin sand beaches, Mediterranean sea, alabaster cliffs, hilly countryside dotted by medieval castles and prehistoric caves. Diversity in food because of all the different climates in the country.

posts.com:
>>2389662
1. Go to Antoine’s. In the French Quarter Fine dining, French cuisine. Do NOT dress casual. Very cheap, complete meal with champagne should cost around 35-40$ if you get the premium items.
2. Johnny’s Po Boys is kind of mid but if you aren’t planning on going outside of New Orleans to taste traditional creole food it’s great.
3. If possible go to a outlying city such as Baton Rouge and get some Boudin (pronounced Boudan and locals get uppity if you pronounce it boudin and will correct you while seething)
3. Take ghost tour of cemetery. It’s stupid but fun.
4. Do NOT book at the Omni or the the W Hotel (Omni is shoebox+ expensive)people will scream and throw shit and you can hear it all night at the W) if cheap enough, go to the Westin. That’s the best place to go and only 5-8 minute walk to French quarter and 10-15 to bourbon street.
5. Go to Cafe Du Monde, but bring a drink beforehand. Drinks are ridiculously expensive there and the beignets will fry you like a motherfucker. Wait times will be anywhere from 15-50 minutes so plan accordingly.
6. Go to Fritzel’s. It’s a jazz club and very kino. Has the authentic New Orleans feel and vibe. Be early or you will not get a seat.
7. Do not take up any people who offer free drinks or anything on the street. They will hustle you. Don’t be a retard and you will be fine.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2367756
There's not much to tell. Probably a meme story on /trv. I went through a long list of terrible life events, both by my own fault and out of my control. Hated my job and considered quitting but I was terminated before I had the chance. I had severance pay and nothing else going for me. My apartment lease was up and I moved my stuff to storage, decided to go to Japan for a few months and maybe end it afterwards or along the way. Once in Japan, I spent a week or two adjusting, and I realized that having daily challenges in life made existential problems go on the back burner.
Met a girl on Tinder while it still was a "friend finder" in Asia. Used her as a tour guide and went to a love hotel a few times. It was casual and I met another girl, who was clingy and (I soon discovered) crazy. Met another. Made friends with Japanese guys and girls (and some expats) and developed a social circle - which didn't last longer than my trip, but amazed me by how easy it was when I wasn't wrapped up in my own head.
Decided that life really wasn't so bad, at least as long as it stayed interesting. And decided not to kill myself and instead looked for ways to earn a living remotely. Applied for jobs until I got one.
In my opinion, the destination I chose was irrelevant. I'd often thought to myself "before I kill myself, I'll go to X country/location". They've varied over the years: California, Africa, India, Japan. When it was time, my destination was Japan. I guess I didn't really want to die because instead of taking the quick jump off an expressway bridge, I actually visited the destination I'd dreamed about. I'm glad I did, and now many years later, I've got kids and I'm happier than I've ever been before. Happier than many of my old friends back in my home country. I wouldn't change a thing.

>Best

>Athens, Greece
Never been somewhere so romantic yet so shitty. Gritty, dirty big city, juxtaposed against a majestic, historic and captivating place full of winding old streets. Beautiful beaches, weird commie anarchist neighbourhoods, vibrant music/arts/history, riot police on every corner at all times, crumbling post-modern architecture and beautiful outdoor cafes. Also beautiful girls, cheap whores and good food.

>Barcelona, Spain.
Not going to go down well on /trv/ but I’ve never had a bad vibe in this city. Big, cosmopolitan and international, modern yet loads of incredibly beautiful streets and neighbourhoods. Constantly has good events, great music/performance scenes and amazing restaurants/bars, imo some of the best in Europe.

In summer, Barcelona transforms into a sunny party city and attracts some of the most incredible women in the world and has one of the best party scenes in Europe.

One thing that I also like about Barcelona is the fact that it’s very much populated with normal, everyday Spanish people and families. Something that is pretty much lost on all of the other big international Western European cities.

>Worst
>Agadir, Morocco.

Filthy Islamic shithole from head to toe. Literally nothing redeeming, interesting or nice about the place. Full of scammers, child beggars, dirty beaches and disgusting food. No history, no historic architecture, zilch.

Literally the only redeeming aspect is the weather in Winter.

>London, England.
I’ve spent more time here than any of the aforementioned cities, IMO London is a soulless, godless place at this stage with very little of value left. Every time I even step foot in London at this point I get this crippling feeling of hopelessness and dread. The people, the local culture and everything in between is just off. It feels like an airport.

>>2367779
>It amazed me how easy it was when I wasn't wrapped up in my own head

This is exactly why I urge people to go backpacking. When you spend a couple weeks (or months, or years) doing the backpacking thing, every day offers something new and you get a new perspective on your problems. I can't explain why, maybe it's because when you're backpacking you tend to make last minute decisions ("Fuck it, I'll skip Nice and take the train to Marseille!") and that makes you realise that you can make decisions about the more important things in your life too.
There is a phenomenon that astronauts come back to Earth with a greater interest in environmental concerns, altruism etc. Because seeing the whole world as just a ball of blue and green has some crazy effects on their beliefs. I think backpacking is kind of similar.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Favorite:
>Chhattisgarh, India: rural and predominately tribal state in east-central India. The whole area has a bad reputation for insurgency and violence, which keeps most visitors away. However, the entire region is incredibly beautiful, insofar it's heavily forested, mountainous, and incredibly biodiverse. It also has some of the most unique and isolated cultures in the entirety of "mainland" India. People are very, very friendly, but not in the obnoxious, quasi-autistic way that North Indians can be friendly. Locals can be a little suspicious of outsiders, but there's zero hassle or harassment. The tribals also make really good alcohol, kek
>Turkey: First country I ever visited outside of the United States. I went for the first time in 2013 and stayed in Istanbul for about a year in 2020-2021. IMO, it's one of the most-visited countries in the world for a reason: the people are extraordinarily hospitable, especially outside of big cities, and the entire country is drop-dead gorgeous. Istanbul is probably--and unironically--one of the most naturally beautiful urban areas in the world. Great views everywhere, reasonably safe, and cheap AF due to the ongoing lira crisis
>Colombia + Mexico: hard tie, can't really pick which I prefer. I'm not a coomer, I just really liked the sort of energy and vibrancy in most big, Latin American cities. If I had to choose one of the two, I'd probably go with Mexico, just because the food is so much better

picrel from a bike trip I took in east-central india earlier this year (sorry for crappy angle, don't have anything better on laptop and too lazy to transfer from phone)

>Athens

The center of Athens has been taken over by immigrants, mostly shitty Pakistanis and Bangladeshis. Greeks have fled the center of Athens to further away exurbs like Korydallos, Marousi, Kifissia, Lagonisi, Gylfada, etc.

In Athens the opposite of what is happening in most of the world is happening. Most the world has seen the city center being reclaimed by the rich and the professional yuppie class and their gentrifying, but in Athens the property market is the reverse, the city center is now a dump that is like an Islamic shitstain country and the outer areas of Athens are more expensive and sought after.

Finally this trip I spent much more time in the wealthier sections on the outer perimeter of Athens and the infrastructure still sucks, but it is nothing like the dystopia that is the Athens city center which is a mini Karachi or Dhaka at this point.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2373726
Btw, I don't want to screw anyone over with this post:

I am not saying or recommending to stay at those exburbs which are further away from almost all the tourist destinations you will want to visit. They are also further from the cultural events if you know Greek.

If you have more money it is probably better to stay in Monastiraki or Plaka that are in the city center but still too expensive for the Islamic riff raff to swarm on the property market. If you have less money it is probably better to stay in Exarcheia which is much cheaper, but poor Greek hippies, arthouse types, anarchists and communists still live there which limits the Islamic floodgate.

I personally have chosen a hotel in the center of Pakistan in Greece, Metaxourgeio. But I know Greek and much more interested in participating in Greek language nightlife(theater, concerts, etc.) and the city center is still closer where most of those venues are located. The nearby subway also has just a few stops till it connects to Trainose(suburban rail line), Omonia, Syntagma, etc.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
best
South Lake Tahoe. It's the most gorgeous place Ive ever seen. The lake is insane. Awesome outdoor bars. Amazing bike trails and hikes. But it still has a downtown area with a lot of good food and bars. Sitting around at the Hangar bar drinking beer by the fire at night under the stars is a vibe that's hard to match.

Jackson Hole Wyoming. The food is shockingly good. Every place in town is like a gourmet cowboy bar. You can do pretty much any outdoor outdoor activity. Whitewater rafting the snake river was one of the best experiences of my life. 3 days in Jackson Hole was not enough.

Maui. The best beaches Ive ever seen were in Makena on Maui. We found a condo for $300/night and that was a really good deal. I bought fresh fish a couple times and just grilled out to cut down on the outrageous restaurant bills we racked up. It's insanely expensive and we probably spent 4 grand on a 6 day trip for the 2 of us, but I felt like it was money well spent.

Worst
Portland Oregon. The memes are true. Portland is a homeless cesspool. There were homeless people camped out front of our Airbnb on a normal suburban street. It was one of the least charming cities Ive ever visited.

Atlantic City New Jersey. We parked the car and someone tried to sell us crack within 30 seconds. It's like vegas with none of the attractions but in the worst neighborhood you've ever seen.

Fresno California. You'll probably never go there, because why would you? I had to stay there for a conference. Your nightly choice of dining options are Dominoes Pizza, and a 24 hour McDonalds. It actually has worse crime than LA.There is literally NOTHING to do.

I’ve been to about 80 countries and I don’t think I genuinely hated any. Yeah there are up and downs but I have always found pleasant surprises. Some countries are better than others, for sure. Then there are countries I won’t really come back because I think I did most of it (tiny little ones).

Countries I liked the most:
- Paraguay: the memories of camping and herding cows with Paraguayan equivalent of gauchos in Chaco when I was kid still haunt me to this day.

- Iceland: did a multi-days trek in the middle of nowhere, in snowy volcanic landscape. Nothing is remotely similar.

- Extremadura in Spain, Yunnan in China in the early 00s, Chile, Lake Tahoe in Burgerland, some swampy place in Skåne Sweden (pic rel) etc. Too many things to list.

My latest trip was a road-trip in Netherlands. I liked it, I learned and saw a lot.
I love traveling so much bros.

>what has changed since 2019?
Forgot to answer this part. First in 2012, then far more substantially in 2019, the Chinese Communist Party forced the Hong Kong government to rewrite large parts of its legal framework (which was supposed to remain untouched until 2047) to align with Chinese law instead of the old British common law. Among other things, HK defendants can now be tried in Mainland China if the CCP demands it. It also purged the HK legislature of anyone who wasn’t fully sympathetic to the CCP.
>I thought they were dropping most of the covid regulations
Nope, just the mandatory quarantine period. Masks are still mandatory, even outside, and they still have a digital vaccine passport system in place with no end date in sight.

posts.name: Anonymous

Best

>Lucerne, Switzerland.
Fucking awesome place, and a great middle ground between alpine city and country. Everything is gorgeous and the kapellbrucke is stellar, but the biggest problem is that everything is fucking expensive as shit, making you feel like a pauper next to all the wealth. My favorite place in the whole world.

>Bend, Oregon.
It's in a very tenuous place as people are beginning to discover it en-masse, but it's a pleasure to visit. Lots of places to go outdoors, lively town, and a young populace. Again, the problem is that granolas and remote techfags are flocking to it, so the future doesn't look so good. Also has the last Blockbuster in the world, which is neat.

>Molde, Norway.
I'm a bit biased because I have family here, but it's a cute town on the waterfront with lots of verticality. Easy to get to the countryside, and the atlantic road isn't far. Just a very pleasant place that follows the beat of its own drum. I'd visit another larger town as a tourist, however.

Turns out my favorite places are all mountainous and expensive. Go figure.

Worst

>San Francisco, California
The biggest tumor of a city I can think of. This is what happens when you have an idyllic region grow for too long, it begins to rot from the inside out. Worse yet, the tumor has metastasized and is starting to infect surrounding regions as well. Fuck this place.

>Milan, Italy
Dirty, expensive, and a worse italian version of Paris. Hosts a bunch of lazy migrants and faux posh italians who think they're above everyone else. The only nice parts are the duomo and last supper mural, and you can see those within a day. Go to Como or Lugano instead, those are FAR superior to this shithole.

>Aberdeen, Washington
No wonder Kurt sang into his shotgun, I would want to die if I had to live in this depressing hellhole too. So desolate and dreary on this part of the coast, and there's plenty of other A-tier places you can go instead if you want to see PNW nature.

My experience is not so wide as some anonii here , but here's mine:

Best:
>Budapest
due to shitty government and inflation, really cheap local restaurants and hotels for other europeans. Nice club scene. Clean enough. Nice views, places to see.

>Berlin
Outstanding nightclubs, some say best in Europe, art, (Turkish kebabs...), culture, liked the overall feel.

> Rome
Walking on history. Been there few times, still lots to see. Cheap af quality red wine. Art, culture etc.

Favourable Mentions:
>Heidelberg, germany
what a nice town between mountains, university town, not too big, nightlife and things to do for a couple days
>Turku, Finland
The town is not big or extremely special, university town and pretty ok nightlife, very safe (as is all Finland). However, you can enter the archipelago from there and it's unique in all of europe or even the world. Some love it to bits, some are not that particular. There are cabins for rent and probably saunas in nearly all habitable islands.

Least recommended - tier (don't actually hate these but wouldnt go again unless necessary):

>Tunis
Well, went there before the Arab Spring and I'm fairly certain it's even shittier now.

>Essen, Germany
You can go there and see a mine. Concrete, not much to do. It's surrounded by nicer places to live probably, but its not for just visiting as a tourist.

>Oulu, Finland
Not much to see, despite being so far upnorth. It's a staging area for trips further north or the islands, but never clicked with the place.

>Reykjavik
The town itself is pretty small and not much to do unless you love whale watching, bathing and seeing the penis museum (OP?). However, Iceland itself is cool in many of the word's meanings.

>San Diego, california
Didn't love the place ,spent a few days, the city itself needs someone to guide you if you want to find anything worthy of seeing.
Still, liked the aircraft carrier - much freedoms for a small fee. Perhaps a nice place to live, however.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Best:

>Hong Kong:
Did my first solo trip here, was totally lost and confused the first day, but after that enjoyed it. Loved the views, amazing hikes, beaches, islands, hills, culture, shopping, amazing food, party scene, booming craft beer scene, chill atmospheres and all in such a close vicinity with amazing accessibility. The hike with the many waterfalls was a highlight, did it with just half a water bottle, a huge hangover and 3 hours of sleep, but loved it so much.

>Istanbul:
Huge city, so much variety in things to see and do. Cultural variety as well. Mosques just a few blocks away from the best Electronic music clubs you can imagine. One of my fav clubs worldwide was very close to Taksim. Turkish food is absolutely top tier, lots of culture and the friendliest people you can imagine. Extremely hectic traffic though, but I didnt mind it that much.

>Rome:
Really hard to choose between Rome and other Italian cities, but how can I choose against a full on open air museum? Great food, friendly people, so much to do and see. Only downside is vendors and a few homeless people, but they are really easy to avoid.

Honorable mentions:
>Florence, Bologna, Madrid, Plovdiv, Varna, Gdansk, Lisbon, Tokyo, Hiroshima, Taipei, Kuala Lumpur

Worst:

>Dubai
Easy pick. Fake and hot. Felt like a ghost town when I visited. Big buildings and huge malls with everything aimed at people who like burning money. Extremely ugly city.

>Paris
Its been a good time since I've been here, but if it wasn't the most chaotic day ever in my life. Many homeless people, druggies and retards just fighting, destroying stuff and creating hassles out of nothing.

>Hoi An
Definitely not as bad as Paris and Dubai. I usually don't really dislike stuff, but I was disappointed when I got here. The bridge is beautiful at night, I had some great craft beer here andgood food, but everything else is just a tourist trap. The bars are shit, the vendors are annoying and the city is ugly, outside of the bridge

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2392773
Bath is not just the Roman baths. The entire city is covered in Georgian architecture and elaborate parks. There's a very specific stone they only quarry there and it's probably one of the best stones for buildings in terms of aesthetics. It's a very, very rich town and it shows the very best of Britain. You can forget you live in England when you are in Bath. Just a stunning place. I worked there for a hostel for a year, the place is pure soul, also I met so many cool people there. BTW - you can get a resident card and enter the bath's for free. They're not too picky about proof of residence, you could literally book a hostel weeks before, have a letter mailed there and use that as a reference. It also works for other attractions and lasts 3 years. If you can be bothered with getting a bicycle, go down the canals to Dundas Aqueduct or cycle thru the mountain in what used to be the railway cutting thru Bath Hills - in fact I recommend hiking around the town on the same hills as you get great views. I detest most things about Britain, the weather, most of the people, ugly architecture, but Bath is an absolute pearl, it's undeniably one of the most beautiful places I have ever been.Somerset is the best place in England. Compared to other big cities Bristol isn't half bad, although I could never live there.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2395220
I used to do a lot of road trips in the US. I found that if I used highways and mostly followed the speed limit, I could count on averaging between 55 and 65 miles per hour with stops to eat, fuel up, smoke, use the toilet, etc. The 55 mph pace is taking it easy, doing sit down meals, etc. The 65 mph pace is making short stops. So, if you want to estimate the travel time, dividing distance in miles by 60 should give a good estimate.

posts.com:
The Czech attitude towards pretty much anything is "I don't give a shit just don't bother me". That goes for weed, it's not technically legal there but there are tons of head shops and references to weed around Prague. I haven't tried getting any over there but I'm guessing you could ask in one of the head shops, or try your luck on a dating app. Otherwise bars like the ones already mentioned are a good bet. Whenever I've smoked weed in other European countries it's been from the Czech Republic and it was good stuff.

Brno is a cool city, not nearly as touristy as Prague. I stayed there for a few nights and went to Moravsky Krumlov to see Alfons Mucha's masterpiece on display in a 900 year old castle. Also the ossuaries are pretty wild.

Cesky Krumlov is beautiful, definitely recommend spending a couple nights there if you like old castles. Also Hluboka nad Vltavou is one of the most beautiful castles in the country and it's not far.

Pilsen is cool but definitely more of a "locals-only" vibe except in the touristy spots like the Pilsner Urquell brewery. The beer and food is pretty exceptional.

posts.com:
>>2391105
If you're used to USA or UK prices then the entirety of the Czech Republic will feel very affordable to you, unless you're trying to stay in high end AirBnbs/hotels and only eat at tourist trap restaurants. For $50 to $100 USD/night you should be able to find very comfortable places to stay in good locations, and I'm sure you can find cheaper stays than that if you really dig.

I think every single restaurant meal I ate in the Czech Republic was less than $15 USD, and that would probably get you an appetizer + entrée + at least one large beer. Otherwise, I would go to a grocery store in the morning and get some bread for like $1.50, some cheese for $2, some meat for $2 and some apples for $2 and be set for the day. Bus, train and tram tickets are extremely affordable, I don't think I've ever paid more than $10 and that was for a longer train ride.

In restaurants make sure you understand how tipping works - for example, after you ask to pay, the waiter will bring the card machine to your table, tell you that the price is 250 Kc, and then you have to say "please make it 300" or whatever you want. I think 10-15% is adequate for a tip there.

>>2390514
Český Krumlov is pretty, but full of Asian tourists
do not visit the Egon Schiele museum there, it is extremely disappointing bordering on tourist trap
imo it's worth it, but Třeboň is a similar experience with much less hassle, you can get amazing fresh fish from the fish farms, and still visit Krumlov for 1 day
>>2389763
you should definitely visit at least 1 castle and do a castle tour, I've been to 10+ and was never disappointed
some even have ren faire style larpers do shows in the castle grounds
people will recommend Karlštejn, the castle itself is nice but the town is a tourist trap, so visit literally any castle that isn't Karlštejn, Prague Castle or Krumlov
you should also go hiking, the ideal case is you make friends with colleagues and visit their "chalupa", or go kayaking/biking/camping in a tent if you're into that
in summer/autumn you can go mushroom picking and hopefully get invited by a colleague for ovocné knedlíčky (fruit dumplings) which is the best Czech food that you can't get in restaurants
you can also try going to the opera at National Theater or Estates Theater in Prague, tickets are very cheap compared to elsewhere, shows almost every night, and the opera houses themselves are really beautiful
even if you don't listen to classical music it might still be fun to mingle with a classy crowd
Black Light Theater is fun too
>>2393053

the Italian place on náměstí Republiky is pretty good too
for desserts and coffee I like Černá madona (expensive but very pretty place) and Ovocný světozor
obligatory reminder that trdelník is not Czech and never will be

People often like to recommend the Asian side for more “authentic”experiences; I’ve stayed in and enjoyed Kadıköy over there, but think it’s silly to write off other parts of town just because. The last time I went to Istanbul I stayed in Cihangir, not far from Taksim, which is a lot more central and full of cafes, nightlife, and hipsters. It’s now my go-to.

I have also stayed in Sultanahmet, close to the big old sites and the most touristy parts of town; except for the fact that the food is more expensive, and arguably not as good, as most other parts of town, and you’ll get touted, it’s actually mostly just fine too.

>yeah that sounds dope
>never hiked in my life
>go to the Victoria outdoor goods store on the main road between Jimbocho and Ogawamachi stations
>spend a buttload of money on gourmet camping food because I don't want to starve in Yakushima island
>instant truffle risottos, dehydrated mutton ragu, all the fanciest food imaginable
>pick up a folding stove and gas canisters, venom extraction kits, basically enough supplies to last through the apocalypse
>pass a bicycle store on the way home
>see a cool looking folding bicycle
>hey this might come in useful, like how else would I get to the trail entrance from wherever the bus drops me off (spoiler - the bus drops you off directly at the trail entrance)
>get the bike, ride it home
>look in my wallet, realize I've just spent nearly all the money I have left for that month
>realize I didn't buy an actual backpack to carry all my stuff, proper shoes for hiking or hiking pants
>barely have enough money left for the train and ferry tickets to actually get to Yakushima from Tokyo
>fuck it, guess I'll wing it
>throw everything in a gym shoulder duffel bag type thing
>get my gym shoes, tshirt and swimming shorts because hey it's probably gonna get hot down there
>I'm ready to climb the summit

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:

>train trip to Kagoshima takes basically the whole day

>don't worry I got this

I work in the tourism industry and have noticed a ton of Europeans who have an interest in visiting hoods (mostly Germans, Dutch, Swedes, and Poles). I have even had some Asian tourists ask me about it.

It's gotten to the point where I'm legitimately considering opening up hood tours. Basically, foreign tourists would pay me to drive them around safely and I would have some contacts so they could get out and visit a corner store etc. or periodically take pictures.

I would start in Oakland (I work in the Bay Area tourism industry) but could see expanding to places like Philly, LA, Chicago, Detroit, NYC (places where foreigners are likely to go or be within a day trip of like Gary or Trenton).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2394137
Look into all the historic things you can see, plenty of Wampanoag museums and culture still around, check out their festivals. There's a lot of nature too, see lakes, marshes, woods, beaches. You will enjoy four distinct seasons. In summer it does get busier but you can easily avoid tourist places. If you know locals they can show you private beaches. Plenty of seafood, the local dish is clam showder. The stores have fresh lobster in them if you want to cook yourself. Whale watching is the major summer activity, whales are really cool. Please try local ice cream, bagels with cream cheese, and clam chowder. If you go out there's a renaissance fair each year, King Richard's fair. If you want fresh apples or pumpkins hit up the orchards or pumpkin patches come autumn. Cranberries are a local product so get cranberry juice, and in the winter the bogs freeze over and you can skate on them. And if you go up to Boston, try to museum of science, and the duck boats. Also randomly I recommend the Christmas Tree Shop, the one by the bridge. All holidays are very festive, Easter especially.

My advice is since it is expensive to find a small place, things close early so don't expect a popping night life, and know it's safe enough people often don't lock doors but never be naive.

Not too far from the ocean too if you want to make a weekend trip to the outer banks its very easy.

Cant really think of any downsides, I want to move there as soon as I graduate.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
If you want beaches, south East QLD. Stay on the southern end of the Gold Coast (ideally south of Burleigh Heads). You can cross the border into NSW which has some of the best rated beaches in the country at Cabarita and Pottsville.

If you want city vibes, go to Melbourne.

If you want a variety of landscapes, go to Tasmania. Most of our mainland has beautiful but samey landscapes for hours on end, whereas Tassy you can see a variety within a few hours drive.

Avoid Sydney. Maybe a day or two to see the famous Harbourside shit, but it is a soulless bugman city. The conservative state government has squeezed any life out of it over the years, there's fuck all to do there now except gamble your pay away and buy overpriced shit. Everything Sydney can offer a tourist is done 4x better by the 3 places I've mentioned.

Personally if I had to spend 2 weeks here I'd spend 8 days touring Tasmania in a van and the rest chilling in Burleigh Heads or Coolangatta on the Gold Coast.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2384843
>Would you recommend visiting Adelaide?
Adelaide has fantastic food, an actual nightlife district (Hindley/Rundle St, but their sidestreets are where the real fun is, with heaps of fantastic cocktail bars, especially Peel St & Leigh St), and is very easy to commute around, along with being far cheaper than Melbourne and Sydney.
As far as beaches go, Adelaide has a lot of nice ones, though if you prefer warmer water and more of a beachside culture, then you'd want Queensland.
If you're coming to Adelaide, there's also a fair few worldclass wineries less than a half hour out of the CBD, and a great deal of great distilleries and breweries. If you're not a drinker, there's fantastic walking trails through the parklands and the Adelaide Hills. It's pretty easy to get to nature from Adelaide too.

Any reason why only 2 weeks?

Like other anons said; must do's:
>Melbourne for nightlife, food, culture/city/architecture - Great Ocean road is awesome too
>Gold Coast for beaches, hinterland, party-esque vibe
>Cairns (Port Douglas) for scenery, snorkelling, wildlife/rainforest, good backpacking scene
That's pretty much your two weeks.

>Tasmania if you have time and want a quieter/more NZ vibe with mountains/unique coastlines
>WA has awesome reefs/beaches but it's to far away from everything else to justify in such a short trip.
>Adelaide for wineries, but same sort of experience can be done at the Victorian peninsulas/Yarra Valley.
>Sydney is pretty meh but go for a day or two if you want to check out Manly/Bondi and the harbour. Blue Mountains is cool, but can do Grampians in Victoria instead too.

Same.
>I'm trying to find a good balance.
What I do is that I only take photos that personally matter to me, e.g. some details of a larger ensemble or people/animals I meet.
When I get back I make a book of my trip using one of those photo book makers by supplementing any missing "big picture" photos with professional photos from Yandex or Bing.

That way I get to stay in the moment and still have a nice memory piece for later.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Guam
AHAHAHAHA
the absolute worst of the colonies

American colonies ranked
>American Samoa
Tribal system of government still intact. Can deny property ownership based on not being Samoan. Based ethnostate. Sadly, becoming a state would destroy the Faʻamatai system to they're better off staying a colony. Amazing people, amazing people, amazing traditions.

>Northern Mariana Islands
Guam minus all the faggots and SJWs. It's a beautiful place with great history. Lots of Japanese speakers and a fuck ton of Asian tourists so you meet interesting people. The most "out there" and mysterious of the colonies.

>Puerto Rico
A bit shady and dangerous... but that's part of the appeal. Beautiful architecture, a vibrant culture, pretty nature. Island Puerto Ricans are infinitely better than Mainlander Puerto Ricans (Gay exiles)

>USVI
A lot of fun. Interesting Danish history and heritage. Bonus points for the fun license plates. Great beaches but you have to watch for crime

>Guam
The fucking worst. Filled with SJW's, annoying military brats, and feminists. Avoid Guam at all costs. If you're on the mainland and meet somebody from Guam, run. They will engage you in a 5 hour lecture on how hard it is to be 1/4th Jap, 1/4th Chamorro, and 1/2 white.

>>2388071
Can't comment on the gender politics; they really don't have anything to do with me, or with you as a foreigner--unless you're staying with local friends you won't have any meaningful contact at all with Gulf Arab family life. Even on business trips there I saw precious little of it--only one of my work contacts in Jeddah is Saudi, and I've only been to his office. The rest are all expats.

But I've been to KSA twice for work, very briefly, and wouldn't go back in a hurry. I was in Jeddah, which is supposedly the most relaxed and cosmopolitan city in the country, and found it an ugly, surprisingly humid, uptight conglomeration of shopping malls. I've also been to the UAE (just Dubai and Abu Dhabi) a bunch of times, mostly for work but also once or twice on transit layovers, and found it nearly but not quite as bad--there's a thin layer of internationally-oriented consumerism and even a hint of debauchery atop your traditional hot concrete desert mess of an absolute monarchy.

It's a weird place, an uneasy combination of enormous wealth and developing-world primitivity. It's weird enough to be sort of interesting in many ways, but I don't find it pleasant.

All that said, I haven't been to any of the region's historical sites, some of which are probably legitimately interesting; the Saudis have promoted them in their bid to develop a tourist economy in ways that I admit look fairly appealing.

But I would sooner vacation almost anywhere else in the world.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2391812
Still here, still in India (although my wife and I are moving to the U.S. in the very near future).

Urban India is modernizing. Educated middle-class Indians have far better earning opportunities than their parents' generation. You'll find many younger people who live very Western-influenced lives. Nevertheless, these people represent a minority of the overall population, even in large cities.

Rural India is much different, and it's incredibly easy to find scenes similar to those depicted in the OP. I have very recently visited insurgency-affected regions of East-Central India wherein I met and spoke to tribal people who had never even heard of "America." It's not especially difficult to step away from modernity here.

I think, to a great extent, much of this "traditional charm" is directly correlated with socioeconomic inequality, poverty, and lack of educational attainment. India still has a distinctive culture, and this culture is apparent and practiced even in wealthier households. I live in a pretty middle-class neighborhood, and there's never a moment I don't doubt or realize that I'm in India (right now, for instance, there's a neighborhood mela and festival ongoing--I am being forced to listen to literally window-shaking devotional music while people scream, shriek, and dance on the road).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2393667
cont.
As India's economy continues to somewhat strengthen, these visible indicators of inequality will--most probably--become less visible. But I don't think that's going to happen any time soon. India isn't going to magically transform into an unrecognizable destination overnight. The next several decades will doubtlessly bring some improvements, but I doubt India is going to become a Westernized or entirely modern country in our lifetimes.

(it's also worth noting that the current political landscape in many states is dominated by Hindu nationalist parties and politicians, almost all of whom are opposed to so-called Westernization, at least when such Westernization doesn't impact their personal earning opportunities)

>>2391822
In respect to clothes and whatnot: this is very, very prevalent, especially in rural areas.

I do think it's worth noting that Western dress among men is very widespread. Even villagers in the middle of bumfuck nowhere often wear t-shirts and jeans. Traditional dress isn't commonly worn except by persons working in certain professions and for special occasions (again, there are many exceptions--I haven't spent as much time in South India as I have elsewhere, but I think farmers and whatnot customarily and very regularly wear lungis. Lower-income Muslim men are another very noticeable exception, as many wear typically Islamic clothing).

(again, can't generalize. I wouldn't bat an eye at a guy wearing a lungi or dhoti in many neighborhoods. It's not uncommon at all)

The trend is different for women. Indian women in cities often wear "ethnic" clothing. Outside of cities, the overwhelming majority of women almost exclusively wear saris and other traditional garments.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>2393674
>How will India combat the brain-drain of its most educated and talented citizen
I would imagine there's no solution other than the continued strengthening and reinforcement of the Indian economy.

I do have friends in their mid- to late-20s who earn the equivalent of $25,000-$40,000 per year with non-STEM degrees. You absolutely do not need to leave India if you're making that amount of money, given that that such an income is likely comparable to a low six-figure salary in most Western countries. However, while millions of Indians are higher-income earners, they still constitute a relatively small percentage of the overall population.

(of course, in the Indian context, any "small percentage" still translates to tens of millions of people)

Again, there's no easy solution. For many people in many industries, it's far too difficult to obtain a respectable salary. One of my brothers-in-law has a graduate degree and works as a tax specialist for a large, U.S.-based company. His American counterparts doing his job make $100,000-$125,000 per year; he makes $800 per month. Obviously many people in similar positions would leave if they had the chance.

Samefag who lives in India.

Many Indians see Canada as an “easy P.R.” country. People who don’t have the credentials or qualifications to move to the United States or Europe often manage to get study or work visas in Canada. Once you’re there, you can sponsor just about anyone else to come over, provided you have the time, money, and resources. The end result is that Canada ends up with the immigrants who couldn’t make it anywhere else, along with all of their under-educated Punjabi and Gujarati relatives.

I do know plenty of normal, well-adjusted Indians in Canada. One of my ex-girlfriends lives in Calgary. She’s a reasonably nice, educated person. One way or another, I don’t really know why Indians who have other opportunities would bother with Canada, were it not for the easy visa. Most of my Indian friends with in-demand degrees and international work experience have said that the Canadian job market is hyper-competitive and that salaries are far lower than what you’d get doing the same work in America.

(of course, America has its own problems. IMO, the States get pretty top-quality Indian immigrants, with younger generations being much more willing to assimilate and intermingle with Americans than their boomer predecessors. The downside is that work-based green cards have country-specific quotas, so there are 15+ year backlogs. I know people who’ve done their PhDs in America, gotten good job offers, and haven’t even reached the point where they’re eligible to apply for permanent residency)

There's a high speed train between Vientiane and the border with China. Actually it goes into China once the Chinese border fully reopens which seems to be getting close.

That's your best bet for public transport between Vientiane, Vang Vieng, Luang Prabang and further north.

To get to the Plain of Jars you'd probably want tot ake a plane. Bus is always available but not great obviously. Some roads are rough.

You can also take boats on the Mekong between difft towns. That's sometimes best option.

Within cities you have standard tuktuks and taxis. They hvae apps now for everything too.

They get a lot of tourists so English is fine if you are within cities and tourist areas.

I was based in Phnom Penh, which colors my perception because it's a shithole. The thing that I really hated was seeing all these really gross, fat, old Australian and English dudes preying on young Cambodian women. A Cambodian guy also tried to mug me, and he was the most pathetic, annoying wannabe mugger ever, all whiny and short. Food was pretty bad too. It made me want to go Taxi Driver on the creeps and kill em all. Which is hypocritical, because I've since honestly fucked a couple latina hookers. I also found Cambodians ugly - they're stocky, thick (not in a good way), and I didn't like their faces.

I just went to the wrong country, though. I've never been to Vietnam or Thailand, but I've known Vietnamese and Thai people. Plenty are gorgeous, the countries look wonderful, and the food's amazing. So I guess what I'd say is, Vietnam and Thailand look awesome, but I'd advise staying the fuck away from Cambodia, or at least Phnom Penh.

Thailand is great. Bkk is a ride if you haven't been to a huge Asian chaotic metropolis before. There's loads of normal travellers, muay Thai fighters and backpackers in addition to the fat whoremongers posting on this site. Just don't go to Pattaya.
I haven't been to Phuket so can't say much about it. Probably very touristic though, same as Koh Samui, koh Phangan and Koh phi phi. Koh Chang is probably the most chill island. I did muay thai in Chiang Mai which was great. The most successful (and most expensive) clubs are I think in phuket, Krabi and and koh Samui. As a westerner even training at a smaller club will be expensive (I think I payed $250$ for a month. Very much worth it though, two training sessions (1-2hrs each) a day plus morning runs 6 days a week. Never had to feed once, always had a Thai trainer hold the pads and correct your form. Unless you are already a pro you improve like crazy. If you do fight you can train in exchange for fighting for the gym (other westerners unless you are a lightweight) but for them to consider it you'll have to train at least a month and be judged skilled enough. Thailand is beautiful and culturally rich.
Thais are generally friendly and easy going although the more touristic the place the more scammers and falser the people.
It's pretty easy to pick up other traveller chicks all over the country. Even easier to pick up locals but I find it a bit hard to wrap my head around personally. There's always the incredible wealth inequality but also (excluding actual streetwalkers) the lines between a normal girl, a slut and a prostitutes is viewed different than where you are from. I think I'd have to stay a bit longer before starting a relationship with a Thai at least.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2391043
>cont
Buses are a bit different. Let me paint you a picture.
You can find super cheap local buses but they lack ac and are packed with Vietnamese along with their babies, chickens and other assorted woodland pets so only the dirtiest of hippies can stand riding in those.

What remains are private operators catering to tourists and upper class with buses with ac and in best case charging ports and stickers lying about on-board WiFi. The website you linked is the only one from the 20 local village travel agents who figured out how to make a webpage and he'll overcharge the living shit out of any sucker he can get his hands on as his competitors down the street have no way of outbidding him.

If you'd visit the competition in person they'd try to sell you seven other "tiers" and operators of deluxe buses for that same route touting theirs as the best and most luxurious. In the end, on the day of departure they will put everyone on the same bus (there's only one) and the ones who booked the 0700 super deluxe 1st class will have to wait two hours for the passengers who booked the budget 0900 bus to board before leaving. But lo, the bus is overbooked! Heated phonecalls from the driver and two of the travel agents appear. After more discussions and phonecalls a rusty heap of a bus with ominous, black fumes surrounding it is summoned. While one travel agent tries to convince the last passengers to board the death trap another realizes they don't need a second bus for 6 passengers. Another deliberation and a minivan loads the passengers. While the unneeded bus driver isn't happy about this, the travel agents hash it out with him as the bus finally leaves, minivan close behind. After a quick 60km detour through winding mountain roads because the driver forgot his lunchbox you are now on your way!

I'd recommend just booking the first two - three nights of accommodation after flying in iot get your bearings and give you time to book the next step on site.

posts.com:
You can find a lot of information/guides on Google desu but I'll try to answer your questions.
>how do i find a good place to live
Lots of websites like booking.com or hostel world can help you find a place, although some would argue you might get better deals on websites directly. I wouldn't stress too much unless you're desperately trying to save money.
>how do i learn important customs in the place i visit/how do i not act retarded.
Again, google can help you. Wikivoyage usually has some tips but there are lots of websites.
>How do i plan my stay?
Look at websites like wikivoyage, lonely planet, tripadvisor etc. Make a list of must do things and some optional stuff if you gave time. Don't over plan it, you should be able to be spontaneous, you never know what might come up. In terms of time, I typically plan 3 or 4 nights per place I'm staying - it can be more or less based on how much time I estimate I'll need.
>then there are also issues like transport
Again, you'll need to use resource websites like wikivoyage. If you're interested in Japan, the Japan general thread has resources in the OP.
Also, not to overwhelm you, but don't forget to look into visa requirements.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2391137
>how to travel i have no idea wtf im doing
First thing's first, what's your budget (how much are you willing to spend total - $3000, $4000)? If you can't afford it then you can't go. Second, where are you going and for how long? You can split your budget by number of days and then check if you have enough money for accomodations, food, tourism, flight, transportation or if it will be unafforadble for you at which point you need to work more and delay your trip. You're from EU so that passport should open a lot of doors for you, some countries may still require you to apply for a visa so check before you buy a ticket if you need to or don't. Also, check restrictions on time limits for visa-free travel (can't go in visa free and stay indefinitely, many places have a 90 day limit).
>what about a place to stay?
hostels, airbnb's, cheap hotels, expensive hotels are all options. You want to focus on WHERE you want to stay. Staying "in tokyo" is not the same as staying "in akihabara in tokyo", you could be a massive distance apart from where you want to realistically spend most of your time. Look for accommodations within your budget in a zone you like, or just next to the zone you want to be in if it's not too far (or if public transport is close, available and reliable).
>what about customs?
dont need to know them for the most part, just know big ones (i.e. no alcohol in muslim countries, no drugs practically anywhere, no nudity in the streets) and just be polite. If you dress well and are polite, no one will bother you, if you fuck up a custom that people care for just apologize and ask for an explanation after telling them you didnt know. What you should know is that if strangers approach you for something, 99% chance its a scam. Strangers will help you, but usually only after YOU ask THEM for help.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2391466 (cont.)
>how do i plan my stay?
Research, and lots of it. You have the internet available, so use it. You can go minimalist and winging it or you can make a full day by day itinerary where you pick certain stops per day and plan a route to visit all of them. If you search online you may find sample routes for places you want to go to which you can alter at will based on your own interests. Look up lists of landmarks, museums, historical sites, hidden gems, hot spots in town and then find out which ones you want to go to and which ones you can skip on. Once you know where to go, find ways to connect them. If they're all in a circle around your accommodation, divide that circle into quadrants and explore it in a loop so you hit your interests and see the town on the way to and back. You can even find quality restaurants ahead of time per area and go to those the day you head out. It's really no different from mapping out a day in your own town. Something like:
>want to go see city hall in my small town
>oh and there's a museum a few blocks away
>there's even a really beautiful park further down from the museum
>it's going to be around lunchtime when I go, theres a restaurant with great reviews between the museum and park so i can stop there
>after the park i'll need to make my way back, but ill return in a circle instead of a straight line back to check out a church and another museum before I leave
It's that simple, people really overestimate planning for travel. It takes a few hours at most to have everything ready, from bookings to day-to-day itineraries.

Speaking of bookings, do not use sites that book for you. Always book directly with an airline/hotel. If there's a problem and you book directly, then the place that fucked you has to deal with you themselves. If a booking agency fucks up, then you don't deal with the hotel or airline, you deal with the agency, which means you're fucked because they won't give you a fix when you need it, only after.

>lost hotel room key
most of those are literally a card so they'll just print another one for you at the front desk on request. So literally just don't be a retard. You realistically only need your phone and wallet with you when you go out, both of which fit in your two front pockets and make it very hard for pickpockets to access. If you're worried about losing your phone, ask for a physical map and have the hotel circle their location so you can show that to a cab driver.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2391137
don't worry too much about it man I'm 20 years old myself and just came back from a trip to Costa Rica. If you head to East Asia, Japan would definitely be the best for beginners, followed by Korea, then China. I haven't been to Japan/Korea myself but I can say with a fair amount of certainty that China would be a little difficult for your first trip and there's more than enough to do in Japan itself to worry about it. If you're on a budget and don't want to blow thousands of dollars on accomodation use hostelworld and stay in a hostel. You'll meet other people roughly your age and solo traveling as well so you can do stuff with them. One thing that other people haven't mentioned is that the moment you arrive you want to go find a SIM card. It's usually not too expensive and I've never paid more than 15 bucks for one, but this way you'll get access to local data without raping your current data plan by using roaming data. Good luck man and just do it, don't let yourself back out because you're too apprehensive to click the button.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2391137
> I know i would be completely fucked if i bought an airline ticket today and winged it
What makes you say that? It's not hard to 'wing it'. The only things you really need to make sure of are:
>Visa requirements
Just google Japan entry requirements for UK citizen or wherever you're from
>Money + money exchange access
I recommend opening a wise account, it's just a debit card you send money to that can pay in 99% of currencies with very low fees (like 0.5%). Avoid using your home debit card, it's probably going to charge a whole lot more than you expect. Using wise card at the ATM is a good idea too, since cash exchanges charge stupid fees.
>Somewhere to stay on your first night out of the airport
Well, you simply don't want to be caught with nowhere to stay.

That's it. You're going to Japan and Korea, both very safe countries, there's no secret shit you need to learn. There are no secret cultural customs you should learn. You're (probably) a white guy, the japs aren't expecting you to know which side of the road to walk on.

>>2391714
>I'll most likely be in Tokyo for the whole 30 days
I get that tokyo is a massive city, but you'd be missing out. Japan has a renowned train network, it wouldn't be hard to get to other places, I'm sure there are a lot of great places outside of tokyo that you can get to easily. You definitely shouldn't try to do a whole tour of Japan with 10 cities in only 2 weeks, but 30 days is a very long time for a single place.

>>2391665

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2391749
On top of this, and most importantly. Allow yourself to be spontaneous.
If you are staying in a hostel (which I highly recommend) and someone invites to do something, it's probably a good idea to go. If someone says there going to some other city and you think it looks like a good place, then you should consider joining them even if it wasn't in your plans. When you're on a holiday you can afford to do that, what else have you got to do, work?
There are two types of people that I HATE when it comes to travelling: picky eaters and over-planners, or people who are too scared to stray from their plan.

Just know where you need to be for your flights, that's important. You might have a few ideas of where you'd like to go, but be flexible, transport and accommodation might not always be in your favour. Or, someone you meet will show you a better location.

Being spontaneous on trips is fun, and it will teach you that every day presents you with millions of decisions, most people don't realise those decisions that they make.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2391753
>Worried about people not speaking english
Google translate, just translate no more than 8-10 words at a time and use simplified english, it works better that way.
>I have to figure out public transport on my own
Typically easier than you imagine. I would be surprised if electronic ticket machines at train stations didn't have a button to display in English. Most developed countries have their public transport loaded on google maps, for longer bus rides that require privately owned transport, use rome2rio. A lot of cities have special 'bus card' things, I guarantee you can buy one of these at the airport with $15 pre loaded onto it.
>Aren't hostels expensive
Almost always cheaper than a hotel. I just searched for accommodation in tokyo on booking dot com and sorted by cheapest, the whole first page was all hostels. Besides, the opportunity to meet people by staying in hostels cannot be bought.

My other tip, take a backpack not wheeled luggage.

Basically Anon, you're 20 years old, you don't need the boring boomer-tier holiday where you have a private apartment your travel agent got you. What you need is a wild ride where you make last minute decisions, meet new people, leave them behind, go places you didn't even know existed, try foods you can't pronounce, walk through parts of the city where taxis don't go, have conversations with people you knew for 3 hours yet will remember forever and come back with photos that actually have interesting stories attached to them.
Would you rather show your friends back home a photo of a statue and say "this is just some old statue, I walked there and went home." or be able to say "I met these 2 american guys who were going to see this statue, so went and saw it with them. I really liked those guys, so I went with them to kyoto the next day."

i'm the same guy as the linked reply OP. I just want to stress the same points that other people made, bring only a backpack (40L-55L max imo, go to r/onebag for more info and realize that you can do laundry abroad) so that you can stay mobile and avoid spending extra money for checked baggage. In addition, I highly agree with being spontaneous. I personally like to AVOID planning too much beforehand because you end up spoiling a little bit of what you're going to see; however, I personally mark places on google maps near where I am staying such that I can do something in case I am bored. Again friend, I hope you end up going through with this trip, I can guarantee that you won't regret it if you stray outside of your comfort zone by trying new things and talking to people within your hostel or just on the street. I know this is 4chan and all of us are socially inward/outcasts in some way, but I can personally tell you that traveling by myself to a foreign country has done wonders to my self confidence (second to boxing) and I find myself far more comfortable with social situations and just talking to complete strangers. Being by yourself in a foreign country makes you lonely, which ends up forcing you to talk to other people you meet (which is a good thing!).

I'm personally jealous that you're able to go to Japan and for so long! I hope you have fun and realize that there will be inevitably be negative parts to traveling, be it fatigue, stress, sickness, social exhaustion, culture shock, etc. Just remember to take in the good and the bad, and savor everything.

Happy travels

did this at your age. went 3 weeks japan+korea and the backpacking to southeast asia. just got a flight to japan, then another to korea and from there to singapore. a few weeks before i booked an airbnb for the whole stay in korea and japan. just booking a hotel for a few days and then planning the rest after works too - i did it this summer in turkey. it was a bit stressful sometimes but it works. when i arrived in singapore at 6am in the morning without sleeping i had nothing booked or planned. literally had to find a hostel on booking.com while i was still at the airport but this worked out completely fine. the rest of the trip i pretty much planned on the go and everything worked out perfectly. traveling alone without planning much is one of the best experiences you ll have. in japan/korea you should probably plan a bit more tho. check what public transport is available and what kind of tickets are cheapest

what to bring aint deep: laptop, phone, cables, clothes, sunglasses, journal, a book, maybe a spare phone if you or a family member has an old one (for a sim card because you are likely to need your own sim card for bank/other accounts nowdays), laundry detergent for traveling, 1-2 thin towels, maybe some cash of the local currency, camera, dildo collection etc. etc.

also dont need to prepare anything really, just check if u need visa etc and maybe places where u wanna go. my tip is to go to hostels or do couchsurfing to meet new peope. find out what (dating) apps you can use to also meet locals. that s how you find out about places/trips you wouldnt have known before

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:

oh and powerbank could be useful especially if you are a phone addict. there is nothing worse than having to stop in a Starbucks because of plugs. also get a power adapter that works for the countries you are visiting (if you have multiple devices optimally one that has multiple ports)

also in japan/korea airbnbs offer portable wifi but you can also borrow them at other places which can be cool instead of simcards. just realize there will be a time period after arriving or before departing where you won't be able to have internet access unless wifi - so make sure to plan ahead so you do not rely on your phone in these moments.

Not a first time JP tourist, N2, - let me tell you a story.
>December pretty bad, economic and everything wise.
>Nice apartment goes for rent, not to bad at about 900 USD/month. We're talking 45sqm or so, 2 mins from Shinjuku, yes really. Old build of 2008 but good enough. 1LDK, separate bath and toliet.
>Paid for everything remote, key money, move in, rent, etc.
>Didn't go Dec.
>Paid Jan, showed up a week ago.
>Decide not to really be in JP this year.
At this point it isn't that bad, we're talking a loss of $2400, which is nothing - but just a hassle.
I missed JP and nostalgia came over me - but the past few days have been meh. I was going in for the angle of getting a cheap apartment before the sprint tourists show up.

Met up/catched up with friends, many of them are 5yr+ in JP, some married/settled down with JP and they're all deciding to fly out, don't blame them really.

Thought about doing some small biz, self sponsered visa, etc - not a big deal - but the work for it just makes annoying. Already run 2 biz, one in USA and one in Asialand. JP seems comfy because it is a great layover spot and a cheap place would be great - but, it does seem a sharehouse would've worked much better at a quarter of the fees.

And that's it. The apartment is the best I've ever had being in JP outside of new build sharehouses but I just don't have time to fuck around as I did 5-8 years ago and that's sad.

I'm still catching up with everyone I know here, and that is nice, and JP is still great - literally 0 tourists, even at the meetup groups. Car rental is not even 1200JPY/day and I had a blast driving around. All the things you guys post on here are cute, but I would say they are worse than 5yrs ago. The girls are super thirsty though and easier, but, they're boring imo. They always were to me. I never liked JP girls, or much of anime. At best music and food.

I do have fun saying I can't speak much Japanese and then act like I'm a natural. It's fun.
